Date: Reviewed in the United States on November 27, 2018
Data:
Five Amazon devices increasingly have problems

I am a 77 year old senior citizen with some disabilities that make it important that I be able to control plugs by voice with my Amazon units.
Three echo devices and two dots have become more and more unreliable. I believe the basic problem is that Amazon has sold so many units that its computers can no longer properly interface with the devices. One of the echo devices is a basic echo, two of the echoes are echo plus units purchased in December 2017, the two echo dots were purchased November 2017, and the basic Amazon echo was purchased July 2017. I have the Alexa app on two android phones. One of the phones is several months old, with the app having been updated relatively recently. The other phone is two days old, and the app was installed on it within the last 48 hours.

Examples of problems

1. Devices are no longer compatible with TP-link Kasa plugs. Yesterday morning the plugs were working fine. Then as the day went on the Alexa devices became unable to control first one of the plugs, then two of the plugs, etc. until it could control none of them.
Here is an example of what happens when I try to turn on a light in my spare bedroom with a voice command. All five of the Alexa devices give the following message:
“Sorry something is wrong. To control the spare bedroom light, try disabling the skill and then re-enabling it from your Alexa app.” Disabling the skill and re-enabling it does not fix the problem. I have the Alexa app on two different android phones.

On both android phones the Alexa app for the nonworking plugs shows a message “Skill is unresponsive.”

If I attempt to manually turn a plug on or off in the Alexa app, the plug does not go on or off. All that happens on either phone is it I get a message stating that the skill is unresponsive. However, if I go into the Kasa app, I can manually turn the plugs on and off–showing that they are connected to the Wi-Fi network. I tried deleting this skill for one of the plugs and then attempted to re-create the skill. The Amazon app was unable to find the Kasa plug.

I spent a long time today on the phone with an Amazon representative who was unable to fix the problem and is escalating it. He said that someone will call me sometime.

There is no doubt in my mind that the problem lies with Amazon. The Alexa app on two different phones states that skills for the Kasa plugs are unresponsive. I spoke with the technician at Kasa who said the problem is with Amazon.

2. Several months ago all of my echo devices began to occasionally respond to a voice command with a statement such as “I’m having trouble understanding right now, please try again later.” If I repeatedly gave the command, eventually the echo device would understand. I sort of felt like I was trying to make a phone call to a very busy line in which the only way to get through was to repeatedly retry.
3. Accuracy of response by all units has declined. Despite my having trained the units to recognize my voice, they increasingly do not properly understand. Sometimes they reply that “I don’t know that one.” Sometimes they state, “I’m not sure” sometimes they carry out an action that I did not ask for–in other words they respond to a command with an incorrect action.

The basic fact is that five different devices purchased at different times are becoming increasingly unreliable and unusable. Another basic fact is that I was unable to get through to a higher level technician and was told that someone would call me sometime. Amazon should stop selling these devices and work on fixing their computers.

After posting the above review, I tried a chat with Amazon and sent this entire review along with a strong request to speak to a supervisor. I was connected finally with a person who helped me restore all of the skills for the tp-link Kasa plugs. There is still the less pressing problem of all of the devices having increasing problems with recognizing commands correctly. The various echo devices are a great idea, but there are still problems I think with the Amazon computers and their interface with such devices.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on August 28, 2018
Data:
I decided to go on a limb and buy and Echo Plus as a way to conveniently play Amazon Music around the house. Previously I had to boot a device or the Smart TV and deal with sometimes complex prompts. The Echo Plus made this process a dream. From the moment I walk in the door I can just tell Alexa to “Play Pandora” or “Play Midland Burn Out.” I can also adjust the volume, skip track, check traffic, pause the music, hear the Dodgers scores, or order a Lyft. All hands free. The sound quality on this device is also quite superb as I can hear it with excellent quality in the room and fair quality in adjacent rooms. I was so pleased with how the device was performing as intended, I quickly decided to investigate some additional perks. Namely, multi room music, the function where with multiple Echo devices, you should be able to simultaneously play music. A network of speakers armed with Alexa sounded great so I ordered an Echo and an Echo Dot to supplement.

This is where things start to fall apart. The initial setup for individual devices is fairly easy. And they all work independently just fine. It’s when I try to group them to play music that they inexplicably can’t be grouped. When I choose the Plus for a group of speakers, the Echo becomes unreachable. And vice versa. One of the main perks of springing the extra dough for the Plus was for this capability and it doesn’t work. Amazon tech support is non-existent as Google is littered with this problem and no solution. The best I could figure is that the Echo is on a firmware version incompatible with the other two. But since there is no way to force your Echo devices to update, it means I have speakers that don’t work until Amazon says so.

Finally, the device is convenient but in no way secure. And I mean in no way secure. Alexa responds to everyone’s voice and there is no option to lock the device like you might your phone. That means anyone in speaking distance can order your Alexa and Amazon account to do all those great things I mentioned earlier. There are no passwords, pins, or voice recognition. Nothing. The Echo Plus can also be controlled and configured by anyone with a smart phone close enough to press the Action Button on top of it. You’d think the device configuration might be guarded via a password or PIN in the Alexa app but that does not appear to be the case either. I’m reasonably okay with these security vulnerabilities since I live alone and rarely have guests. However, if I still had Airbnb guests, roommates, or regular visitors, I would be extremely nervous about leaving these things around. Which is unfortunate since the speaker functionality is nice but you don’t exactly want to share power over all of Amazon to anyone who listens to your speakers.

The bottom line is that the speakers work great to play music in a single room and it can potentially simplify many things that you might’ve previous had to pull up the Google for but the implementation is unpolished at best and the security implementations are non-existent. And non-existent to a point where Amazon was really just being lazy. Even a 4 digit code or pass phrase option could be a crude yet simple way to guard against unauthorized purchases and yet they are absent.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on November 9, 2017
Data:
I really did like my echo plus at first but after really playing around with it I didn't notice any real differences from the echo dot's we already have. We now have 2 dot's with the vaux speaker addons and this echo plus. We are relatively new smart home device users and only have the hue bulb that came with the echo and we didn't have any issues setting up the bulb and have been really enjoying it honestly. At first my girlfriend was very skeptical of this whole system and I was as well, we are the people who have siri completely disabled on all of our devices, iphones, ipads, apple watches, macs etc we turn it all off. So far "echo" (we don't care to call it a human name we find that weird so we changed it to echo because that's what it's real name is and it's less weird to us) has been really good at hearing us from across rooms or while playing music, the echo plus really doesn't seem that it's that much better in terms of audio quality or voice recognition when compared to the echo dot with the vaux speaker ($84.99 bundled fyi versus $149.99) and the echo plus also has no portability where the echo dot with the vaux speaker can be unplugged and used for 6 hours on a rechargeable battery. The bass from the echo plus itself is better than the dot with the vaux speaker but the treble isn't that much clearer to me to be honest. I have also heard there is alot of compatibility issues with the echo plus and that it isn't really a "smart hub" like it's advertised to be which really is misleading about the product itself....

Overall I really do like all of our echo's I just feel that amazon dropped the ball on the development of the echo plus, I would've even paid a little more for a better more premium product that really is what they made it sound to be but honestly if you don't need the mediocre smart hub on the plus you could save alot of money just buying the dot with vaux speaker ($84.99) or just the new echo ($99.99), my girlfriend and I are now not really uncomfortable buying more smart home products because we don't know what really works with the new echo plus and what doesn't...

*Also* If you have spotify premium family subscription you and another family member can't play music in different rooms at the same time on different accounts which is really annoying because we both have different tastes in music and want to play our own music when we are in the living room, cooking, relaxing in the bedroom...etc, kind of a let down honestly, maybe there is a way to do it but the Alexa app is not a good app so far and is not very easy to use whatsoever it feels very "third party" if you know what I mean...

Data:
Let me edit this review and say that -- after 2 1/2 HOURS on the phone and several additional days of back and forth, Amazon did ultimately replace this defective Echo.

I'll also say that I have several Echos and I like them quite a bit. And let me also say as a bona fide tech geek that even great equipment can have individual defective units.

So, it's not the device that's my problem. My problem is that the first level of tech support are not only poorly trained but have no authority to resolve the issue. Was on the phone for more than TWO HOURS with a tech. I've deleted the absurd convo but suffice it to say it was embarrassing. He didn't seem to understand that the Plus even has a Hub, nor what a Hub does in relation to the normal Echo capabilities. Consequently, he couldn't grasp how the Echo could be working but the Hub not. Nor that light bulbs cannot work without a hub of some kind. Nor that you can't "reset" a light bulb other then by turning it on and off.

It was ultimately escalated and the unit replaced. But the process was ridiculous for a device of this cost.

Compare this experience with Apple. I had a pair of Beat Headphones that cost more than twice the price of the Echo. I'll spare the boring technical problem but it had to do with not being able to reset them to resolve a connectivity issue. I got to the Apple store and, as these things sometimes go, I couldn't actually replicate the problem -- they were temporarily working fine. The response of Apple was, "yeah, don't worry about it, we are aware that this is an issue from time to time. So let us just swap you out for a new pair."

THAT'S how customer service works.

Original review:

Let me begin by saying that I've been a huge fan of Amazon, a shareholder and a Prime Member for as long as I can remember. This is my THIRD Echo device and I had no problems with the prior ones. So I would think they would jump to make me happy on this one. First the device had problems responding, would say it lost the internet connection despite the fact that the other two Echos worked fine. Then the hub could no longer find the smart devices that it had been connected to and worked fine with for two months. I assumed the tech team would jump to make this right. I was on the phone for MORE THAN TWO HOURS with people who seemed to know much less about Amazon's devices than I do but didn't seem to have the authority to replace an $88 device. What follows is the THIRD support conversation. You'll see it's pretty incredible.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on March 7, 2018
Data: I have been an Echo owner since day one. I've also had the Philips Hue lighting system. - Previous to upgrading to the Echo Plus, I controlled all lights through the Philips Hue App. One main function I used was to be able to turn on and off certain lights based on Sunset (Dusk) or Sunrise (Dawn). - I control several lights in this manner. - When the Echo Plus with built in hub was announced, I contacted Amazon by phone to speak with tech support to ask weather or not the Echo Plus will work with Philips Hue Lights (Which they said it did) and if I would be able to turn lights on and off based on sunset, etc. - I was told that it would. So when I had heard this, I ordered the Echo Plus which would arrive in 2 days. Meanwhile, I had someone from out of state over and they wanted my Gen 1 Echo. I gave it to them, along with the bridge. I figured I could live without Alexa for a few days. - After receiving the echo plus, I had the task of setting up all my Philips Hue bulbs with the new hub built in to the Echo Plus. After some doing, all of them were now on the new hub and functioning properly. - I then went to set up Routines for my lights to basically set schedules, etc. Low and behold, that is when I found out the ability to do what I want is not available. - My only choice is to turn a light on or off based on time. - As we all know, The time the sun sets varies every day. So the on;y choice is to go in and modify routines manually every week or two. Not quite the Smarthome I was looking for. Look, I get that the product was brand new and it needed some tweaking, etc. - My issue is that most updates we see for Alexa are things that have nothing to do with smarthomes. Do I really care to hear a (bad) jike from Alexa? Do I careto hear her sing? I for one do not. If you were to ask Alexa what time the sun sets, you will get a correct answer. So I know the ability is there and is a simple modification to Routines. - The unit sounds great, looks very cool and is built very well. Just wish Amazon would concentrate more on the "Smarthome" portion of the Echo Plus.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on December 3, 2017
Data:
I actually really like the concept of the product. It is fun just to play around with, but difficult to operate, which I'll go into detail about later. The built-in hub isn't necessary, unless you plan on buying one smart light bulb are a time because the packs come with a hub free (an echo dot is sufficient and cheaper). The speaker quality is great for music and can be increased fairly loud without distortion.

Now for the difficulty with operating. For starters, your echo doesn't have many bells and whistles prepackaged. You have to search skills, which are kind of like apps or lessons to teach Alexa. There are many different skills you can teach Alexa, so make sure you have time to look through them. Now you've taught Alexa skills, but for every skill you must remember how to communicate exactly as instructed on the skill page or Alexa will not understand (e.g. "Alexa, tell <skill name> to perform such and such task). If you don't remember the phrases to get Alexa to perform the skill you can always look through your app and under skills to find directions. Who will remember all the specific wording for each skill? Plus, the whole point in speaking to Alexa is that it's hands-free, so looking at the app for directions isn't convenient. It gets very frustrating if you don't have the Alexa app handy. Next, if you plan on controlling plugs or lights with Alexa you have to download apps from the manufacturer. Your now cluttered phone is even more cluttered and you don't speak the same language as Alexa. She also has difficulty understanding a lot of questions and you have to rephrase them several times for her to give you any answer.

I love, love, love the functions I can remember the wording for Alexa to perform the task. There are so many things Alexa can do that listing them would make this review entirely too long. I will list my favorites and most useful to me.
Turns on lights or plugs. Groups lights, traffic report, weather, and many other functions together to be performed with one command (e.g. "Alexa, good morning"). Orders pizza. Tells jokes. Gives answers to questions you have. Controls TV. Sends messages and makes calls. Adds things to grocery lists. Sets reminders so you won't forget things. Adds appointments to your phone or email linked calendar. Helps kids with homework. Plays games for adults and kids.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on December 17, 2017
Data:
This is my first foray into the Amazon ecosystem. I wanted to get my feet wet with some smart home capabilities and was interested in using the Echo Plus as a hub. This device can be really easy to setup BUT it may drive you crazy first. I ordered the device on my account and it came registered to my account and Amazon profile. My wife is the official Prime member. During the initial setup process the Echo switched to her profile unknowingly to me. Thus, as I added smart devices to the Alexa app and was able to control the via the app, Alexa via voice control through the Echo Plus could not discover any new devices. I called Amazon for help after several hours troubleshooting myself. The support person was useless going through a script trying things I had already done such as rebooting. I gave up with this person and worked several more hours on my own. The next day I was ready to send the Echo Plus back but first I thought I would call Amazon support and try again.

This time the support person was much better. We worked for about 30 minutes before discovering by accident that the Echo was not set to my profile! Thus, here is the warning, the Echo Plus has user profiles and you must be using the same profile in use on Echo Plus and your Alexa app! Duh! Just ask Alexa, who’s profile or account is this? Then the setup was extremely easy.

I have read reviews complaining about the sound. However, I have been very pleased with the quality of the sound. It not a sound system bout for one speaker it does a great job.

In terms of controlling smart devices, Alexa works very well and is integrated with many of the devices I already had in use. My biggest problem is remembering what each light is named.

Finally, the Amazon profiles are problematic. My wife and I have to continually switch back and forth between profiles to listen to music or control devices. Yes, we have set up a family profile but that doesn’t resolve this issue of using a specific profile for a particular purpose.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on January 25, 2018
Data: Its a start but I expected much more by now, Something as simple as tell it to turn on certain lights on at dusk and then off at dawn, or even on at Xtime off at X time but it can’t even do that. this is my 5th echo and second dot So Im not some newbie expecting the world. In my mind you have my geographic coordinates and my time zone either of these things should have been very easy and included but neither are. as for the sound it is far superior to the older units, and this brings up another issue we use the everywhere feature to play the same station or stream through out the house and if you are playing music its ok but if you put on talk radio and you find your ears between 2 units as you walk from room to room you get a horribly annoying echo where they are a couple milliseconds out of sink. before someone comes back and starts blaming my WIFI NO ITS NOT we just had a brand new commercial wifi and network management system installed just like they use in hospitals and office buildings its all Ubiquiti Unifi and there are AC 1200 in room access points in 7 of the 11 rooms in my house and an outdoor unit with an antenna array designed to cover the entire 6 acres of our property, that being said I got my first unit several years ago and have been adding to them over time and they have made some great improvements and many steps backwards teach iteration of updates seems to fix a few quirks and create a few, My most current complaint is how often they light up and start listening when the wake word nor anything like it has been spoken and I changed the wake word to the less likely one so I don't understand why I might be sitting in a room reading a book and the thing will light up and listen when nothing has been said, and when you do talk to it especially the dots you have to speak in a loud tone to get them to trigger. Those are my thoughts from my personal experience, I hope this helps.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on February 12, 2018
Data: After a 3 month honeymoon, I am disappointed in my Echo devices because they are not as easy to use or exciting as marketed. I get so frustrated with my Alexa devices because they will only do what I ask them to do about 40% of the time! Those cute little TV ads that give cute little nonchalant commands to Alexa are so misleading as the devices do not work like that in the real world! Unless you know exactly what to say to make a Skill work...Alexa will not find the skill or recognize your command...or worse, she will ignore you! And yes, Alexa even plays a specific sound to tell you she is ignoring you! I have spent countless hours researching and working with the devices to improve their learning curve but find it too frustrating and time-consuming to figure out what the Echo wants to hear to function properly! I have resorted to writing down and memorizing the exact statements they want to hear in order to get my devices to actually do what I want them to do. Right now I have a 6-page list laying beside the device reminding me what I have to say to make each skill work on Echo! On the positive side, I have really enjoyed having the Smart Home devices that Echo pairs with....my Smart Plugs and Sensi Thermostat. Having Alexa turn on my upstairs lights before I get upstairs, make coffee for me before I go to the Kitchen, and turn my Thermostat up to warm my house while I am still in bed has been wonderful! I also love the Alexa My Buddy Skill that allows you to set up 5 friends and family members that the skill will alert if you have an emergency at your home and can't reach your phone. It will email, text and call those on your list and alert them to check on you. Although I am disappointed and frustrated with my Echo Plus and Dot most of the time..... I do love the convenience and peace of mind the Smart Home devices (paired with them ) have brought into my life!

Date: Reviewed in the United States on December 30, 2017
Data: I bought my first echo as a “plus” model thinking it would make life easier. After the first unit arrived with a dead speaker Amazon did a great job of having me unit number two within two days. After resetting all the lights for the new Echo Plus hub I started really looking at what the Hue system could do. Why not I had a built in hub right? After reading questions and answers on motion detectors and other accessories besides light bulbs I thought I bought what would be a compatible sensor only to find out that while it is recognized by the Echo Plus hub it cannot be used. No options exist inside the Alexa app to make assignments or change settings to the motion sensors. That’s when I discovered I now need a $50 Hue Bridge to make it all work. So the bottom line is my $149 Echo Plus can be retuned and be replaced with a $79 Echo and a $50 bridge. Saves me $20 in the end. Ignore this one. Get an Echo and a bridge. You need it anyway. I love what the echo can do and Alexa is quite handy. I’m a bit disturbed by the marketing on this one though. If all you want to do is dim lights you will be happy. If you want to actually automate things you will need more equipment. The sound from the Echo vs the Plus is neglible. If I recall the speaker diameter difference is 2/10’s of an inch. I have a second generation Echo as well and I can’t tell much difference in sound quality. It may even be where the units are sitting.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on December 1, 2018
Data:
I had been the last holdout of all of my friends when it came to purchasing an Echo because I didn't feel its functionality was initially worth it, after all I have a spotify account that connects to wireless speakers, my friends' echos always understand the men better than the women so why have something that doesn't understand me, etc. However, I'd been planning to purchase a philips hue system and when the alexa plus came out, the advertisement that a bridge isn't needed finally made it worthwhile.

However, my impression since receiving this in July 2018 and finally setting it up a month or so later: she's a disappointment. The speakers of this 1st generation echo plus are WORSE than the original Echo. She still doesn't always understand me. She loses connectivity to the dot half the time. And then there is the final and biggest disappointment: I STILL have to purchase a Hue bridge because while you can turn the lights on/off, you can't access the color wheel or create scenes through the Plus.

I suppose I should have been more cynical about what Amazon said and checked with Philips that the Plus really did replace a bridge vs just taking on a functionality I could easily set up with the existing app. Sadly, I was out of the return window by the time I tried it out and since Amazon upgraded the device, I imagine they won't let me replace it in case i just received a lemon with lower grade speakers.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on December 20, 2017
Data:
So I had bot the Echo and teh Google Home and really liked both of them. Ultimately I kept the Google Home for 2 reasons.

1) Echo will not do multiple accounts with Spotify. It will only connect to the Main Spotify account owner and any family members are out of luck. Any play list being played is from the Main Spotify account. You can;t even set up the family members. Also with multiple Echo users you have to say switch account to "so and so" but it still uses a shared calendar, list etc. Google Home can recognize up to 6 different users just by voice and will use that persons calendar , list or yes---- SPOTIFY! You don;t even have to say switch accounts.

2) Echo will not grab or play anything from YouTube.

Also I tried various questions on both Echo and Google Home - Echo was stumped way more than Goggle Home and Google home had more variety and funnier replies when I would ask goofy things just to see what would happen

Both device are great tech but the mentioned issues were deal-breakers for me. So now I have a house full of Google Home devices and speakers so by the time the amazon echo addresses the issue sit will be too late because I will be so deep in the Google Home ecosystem. Kind of a bad play on Amazon's part because I bought the Echo first and had the new Dots on pre-order - they had me but lost me.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on July 23, 2018
Data: We are a long time Amazon Prime family, many years, but new to the Alexa world and thought the purchase of Alexa Plus, with hub, and included Phillips Hue light bulb would be a great start. Alexa does a lot of good things for us like Alarm in the morning, verbalize books, playing music on command, even linked to my Sirrius/xm account. Good daily stuff. Good sound, but not Bose. But, the ads say "Hub included" so don't need anything else to operate devices. Well, not so. I understand there will be some differences in product device support. The fact that it came with the Hue light bulb works only for on /off/ dimming of the bulb. The bulb is capable of so much more with the Hue App but the Hue app does not recognize Alexa hub as a bridge. So, it appears you do have to get a Philips bridge to set the bulbs for scenes, time the lights when you are away, set color tones, etc. That can all be done via internet with your phone or tablet away from home. The list goes on for its capabilities but not without its own bridge. Was very disappointed to find that out after the fact, to the point I feel we are being misled by Amazon by included the Hue bulbs without explanation. Maybe throw a good discount my way to get the Hue bridge if I keep the Echo Plus before I invest in more light bulbs.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on November 3, 2017
Data: I wanted another Echo with built in speaker because one of my Echo dots has trouble maintaining a connection with Amazon's own Bluetooth speaker. I like the volume ring (the new regular Echo does not have it), so I decided to try the new Echo Plus with built in Zigbee hub and a bonus Phillips Hue bulb. I thought it might be nice to experiment with home automation, for basically the same price as I paid for my original Echo. The result is underwhelming. Setup was extremely easy. The new Echo sounds just like the old one. But not discernably better. I can indeed control the Phillips bulb with Alexa. However, this control is limited to "on", "off", and dimming. This is fun for a minute. then you realize that the bulb can ONLY be controlled by voice or app. If it is turned off by switch, it's off until switched on again by hand. I realized that I'll rarely if ever use it. Also, I had expected a more robust set of controls, like timers that would work just like Alexa 's alarms ("Alexa, turn on my bedside lamp every weekday at 7am"). It seems natural. But alas, no. The new Echo is fine, but i realize now that I'm not really into voice control. If i could do more with true automation and the app, i might be back for more.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on August 30, 2018
Data: I am not a very tech savvy person so this is a review for those of you looking to jump onto the smart home band wagon but don’t have a ton of tech knowledge. I was excited about the echo plus because it seemed to eliminate the need for additional hubs-the middle man between Alexa and smart devices. I felt like I did a lot of research before buying this echo and before buying my smart home devices but apparently I didn’t read the fine print. In the description of the Echo Plus it says that it is compatible with all ZigBee devices and there is a hot link which takes you what I would assume were these ZigBee compatible devices. I bought a Schlage lock and some light switches that were listed on this page but much to my dismay my Echo Plus could NOT discover them no matter what I did. Then I dug deeper into the Alexa app-specifically the skills page and found out that the lock and light switches were in fact NOT compatible with this hub and required a separate $85 smart things hub. I was very disappointed and felt misled by the initial link to supposedly compatible devices. There is no point in paying the extra money for the PLUS if you are going to need to buy a separate hub anyway. I will likely return mine and just get a standard Echo.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on April 24, 2018
Data: It has trouble understanding words compared to other voice operated systems. I changed the wake word to “computer” to avoid tv adverts and web videos from doing silly things, but it often activates as I train my dog to “come here” everyday. Even with voice training, it’s difficult for it to recognize who is speaking. It fails to understand relationships like “call my brother” or “who is my sister”. I’m often asking it to do things and surprised at its inability to understand the context. Turn on the lights “many devices share that name”. Turn on all lights. “No device by that name”. Computer end program. “No program by that name”. To me, this is a very limited system. You can not customize the wake word other than choosing from three options. You can not choose it’s voice, or the chimes for when it is activated. I can live with it, but in its current state, I find it frustrating having to rephrase what I’m asking five times before it is able to comply. My phone is much easier to speak to with custom voices and portable. Currently I use this to operate lights and listen to music. It’s unable to detect color lightbulbs without a bridge, but it can detect regular ones just fine. People like playing with it at parties. In a house, you’ll probably need to expand with a few dots in rooms that you often hang out in.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on November 7, 2017
Data:
It is 11-06-2017. I Love my gen 1 Alexa. I have been using it every day since release. I have an Alexa gen1 & gen 2 in a group. One in each living room downstairs. My Alexa is playing in groups without me telling it the group name. it won't play on a single echo, it just defaults to group play. I have to unplug the echo plus to rest it. Then it works fine for a short while. Then it just starts defaulting to group play. Very frustrating. I hope they fix all these bugs because I love my Alexa. I use it every day, primarily for music. I just want to be able to use group when I say the group name. Once I activate the group name it won't ungroup unless I unplug it to reset it. Echo Gen 1 gets 5 stars. I'm holding out hope for the Echo Plus.
UPDATE:11-8-2017
Alexa plus won't play spotify. I tell Alexa plus to play spotify. Alexa plus says playing spotify and nothing happens. I Walk into the the other Room and tell Alexa 1st Gen to play spotify and spotify starts playing. This is consistently happening. Please Amazon fix these bugs. This Eco plus is consistently giving me problems whereas the 1st generation Alexa doesn't give me problems at all.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on November 22, 2017
Data:
The Echo Plus sounds pretty good, though it doesn't seem to have the same audio punch as the original Echo. The tweeter is smaller and it doesn't have bass assist like the original, and the person at Customer Service that I spoke with was pretty clueless and never gave me a satisfactory answer as to why it would sound better.

But ultimately, my biggest disappointment is that all the ads pushed it as having a built in hub, so I bought it to replace my Wink Hub, to try and simplify. But once I disconnected the Wink Hub, the Echo Plus did not recognize any of my light bulbs or my Emerson thermostat, even though they were supposedly compatible. So I had to reconnect my Wink Hub, and the Echo Plus doesn't seem to provide any more functionality than the original Echo. If it is not going to act as an independent hub that can work with all the compatible components, don't mislead the customers.

If I had to do it over again, I would just have bought another original Echo, and skipped the Echo Plus. The inability of the Echo to act as a true hub is a deal breaker.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on January 25, 2018
Data:
I return to put my review because amazon did not allow me to put it in Spanish (it seems discriminatory, but I'll put it in English)

The speaker leaves much to be desired, it is supposed to come with an integrated bridge so you do not have to buy it separately and although it detects the smart devices, if you do not buy the bridges of each device you will not be able to make use of the maximum of its functionalities. The instructions that you have to give are highly specific unlike Google home that you understand faster.

language? Not to mention, only understand English, I think they should expand quickly to other languages such as Spanish if they do not want Google to win the Latino market.

the calls are of poor quality, the person I call them does not recognize my voice or fully understand what I say.

When I ask for a song from Spotify, I do not always understand the song I want it to play.

there is a news app in Spanish but alexa reads them and reads them really badly, they should include some direct telemundo platform or something like that.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on December 25, 2017
Data:
I purchased this item along with several Echo dots to connect around our house. After using them for several weeks, I have noted that Alexa does not give full answers to many questions. If you ask about a particular topic, she will find a Wikipedia or other response but only speak the first couple of lines which do not answer the question. She can find a recipe but not email it to you.

Alexa also has difficulty answering many questions. She will just respond with "I'm sorry, I don't know that." If I have to google the answer there is no point in asking the question.

Music streaming sound on this speaker and the dots is awesome, however, the Echo and dots will suddenly stop in the middle of an album. If you ask Alexa why she will apologize and tell you to report it on the Alexa app. Also she cannot find many of the albums that I know are available on unlimited Amazon Music because I stream them on my phone.

These are amazing speakers but the Alexa technology needs more training. I look forward to software updates.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on September 9, 2018
Data:
I have a love/hate relationship with this product, for instance:
I asked it "Who wrote Murders in the Rue Morgue" It replied, "Edgar Allan Poe, Gaston Leroux, Christopher Wieling. The last two were screen writers. It took the info from Wikipedia. I'm glad that I'm not a school student.

Timers work intermittently. (I reported this previously) At times I try to set a timer e.g. "Set timer for 10 Minutes" Echo response: "Ten minutes starting now" But the timer doesn't work. If I check the Echo app online, it doesn't show a timer requested.

I cannot set a reminder for a time/day more than 24 hours in the future.

I have not figured how to put hub enabled lights on a schedule, for instance "Turn first light on at 8PM today, and off at 7AM tomorrow" or even better "Turn first light on every day at 8 PM and turn off every day at 7AM. This may be possible, but I have not found a way to do it.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on January 10, 2018
Data: I like Echo, but I really hope there is far more integration and development planned. Because I'm VERY new to this, MAYBE some of these features are already built in, and I have not found a way to those features, but being able to see what is available to watch on my fios TV based on my location and past TV preferences would be nice, being able to add to my amazon wish list via echo and have echo read out a list content would also be nice. Less strict wording of common commands needs to be added.. ie: I like sitting in the den with "colorloop" running on my colored HUE bulbs. Generally it takes me 4-5 tries to get "colorloop" running via echo. I go through this every night. I thought Alexa got smarter as time went on. Being able to set a reminder or timer to other or ALL devices or dots would be nice so I can move around the house and still get reminded. There is more, but I'm looking forward to seeing how Echo develops.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on February 25, 2018
Data: Sure home automation is still in it's infancy, but the Echo Plus is amazing! She helps me get up and tells me how traffic will be on my way to work and she helps put me to sleep at night with sleep sounds. Will definitely be expanding my home automation and buying more Echo devices, the amount of time saved by this device is worth the purchase price. Thank you Amazon, you have delivered yet again!! Update 12/28/2018 Lost 2 stars because Wi-Fi module went out in less than a year and had to ship it back. They sent me a replacement but never told me to keep my old power cord, so another week without one and they only gave me a 19.99 credit to order another (why they couldn't just send me one?) but I ended up paying out of my pocket the tax since they didn't credit that...Greatly disappointed by Amazon on this one, might switch to Google Home!

Date: Reviewed in the United States on January 17, 2018
Data: I like my Echo plus I know as digital assistances evolves they will become better; For this reason I bought only one. They should have had a woman on the team to bring a balance. You can tell Alexa was made in a man's world. We asked Alexa what she was designed to do a woman on the team would say assist; Alexa said I don't know. I wanted to wake up to music, but no way to program. When told to shut down it is still on sometimes it goes off and at other times it doesnt.Alexa does not change voices that would have been fun. When telling it to program reminders it doesn't repeat back the reason for the reminder. It saids a lot of Sorry I don't know that. So bottom line I would buy the less expensive version and wait for improvements.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on March 6, 2018
Data: 2 stars lost because of the Plus. The plus is no plus in that it just doesn't work right. I've since had to purchase a Hue Hub separately in order to get my devices to work 'correctly' I love all the Echo devices in general, but Amazon needs to send their Echo Plus back to the drawing board to make it actually work, and enhance it be able to actually be useful. I also had to buy a different Bridge, A Smart Things Bridge, because the Echo Plus is only for ZigBee L (light) or something? I don't remember, I don't care any more. But if you're going to build a product with a built in hub, make it one that is all inclusive, or go home. I have 6 echo devises in total, and the Echo Plus has been a nightmare.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on November 9, 2017
Data: I was very excited about this product, but got disappointed. After debating between the Philips Hue bridge and the Echo Plus, I got this primarily to set up my Philips Hue smart bulbs in my house. As it turns out, the Echo Plus indeed serves as a bridge for the bulbs, but then that's it. It doesn't do anything else besides that. You can dim, turn off and on etc using Alexa, but nothing more. So now I have to go back and buy the Philips Hue bridge in addition to this if I want to be able to control the color of my lights, automation, and such. That's my only disappointment. I thought it was going to function fully as the Hue Bridge does. Otherwise, it was a great purchase. The one thing I love about the device is the quality of the sound. Really awesome sound.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on March 9, 2018
Data: I wasn't aware that it would interfere with my wifi and many additional units would count individually against the wifi max units. I was surprised to learn that I didn't need another hub to operate white lights, e.g. hue from Phillips. Speaking in the words Alexa understands is sometimes problematic as she does not respond as expected. I am still learning how to coordinate functions with Alexa. A simple task, such as acting like a timer for a light to turn on and off is far more difficult than I was prepared for and as of now still not accomplished because there are no examples to follow for that setup. Using it as a countdown timer works very well. Addons will come slower than I anticipated now. I also was not aware that Alexa only updates its information yearly while others update much more frequently.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on December 16, 2017
Data:
I really enjoy the Echo Plus. It's nice having a home hub and the echo in one device. This is my first foray into smart home equipment. The only thing I don't like about this, is that even the smart home connection stuff (on the same WiFi network) has to go through the internet, and then back to your house.
My internet went out the other night, no big deal I thought. "Alexa, turn off the living room lights." nothing happens. Usually not a big deal, but I have some Christmas lights hooked up to it as well with the switch in a high, hidden spot. Just frustrating that being a "hub" it still has to communicate to the smart devices via the internet. If the WiFi is still running, but the internet is down, it shouldn't stop your connected devices to your "hub."

Date: Reviewed in the United States on November 22, 2017
Data:
I've only had it a little more than 2 weeks, so take that into consideration.

What it does well, is help automate your home, with it's built in hub. I've added bulbs and a led light strip, so far, and it's done it's job flawlessly. I do plan to continue adding on with a thermostat and security cameras.

What it doesn't do well is answering questions. Approximately 60% of the time, Alexa doesn't understand the question. Which really means she doesn't have an answer. While watching the Bucs/Dolphins game on tv, I asked Alexa for the score, she told me they play next week. They had a scheduled bye this week,but hurricane Irma took that away week one.

Arbitrary questions don't get answered very often, specific business, weather, sports questions are generally answered.

I'm hoping that updates will help with this.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on November 6, 2017
Data:
First time echo owner... have been a bit underwhelmed at this point. It is difficult to find compatible smart home devices and even when you do, setting them up can be quirky. It says that it has Bluetooth capability, yet apparently I cannot connect to GE Bluetooth smart home devices without an Avi-on "remote access bridge". So, what is the point of the Bluetooth capability? Just to connect your phone and use it as a speaker? Also, with no support for z-wave, I'll have to keep my hub for those devices as well.

Sound quality is okay...
App is a bit clumsy and unorganized
Doesn't work with my Xfinity Home security system
Very limited control of my Honey Well WiFi Thermostat

I hope that the launch of this device will spur development of Zigbee devices.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on December 17, 2017
Data:
I have the Echo 2nd Gen, two Dots, and the Plus....and the Plus is supposed to be the most advanced I thought? I purchased it so that I wouldn't have to buy hubs for all my different smart devices--while it does make it super easy to set things up, it seems to be the "most dumb" of all my Echoes. My Dot all the way in the kitchen picks up what I'm saying even if I'm a foot away from the Plus! It's very annoying. I've tried putting them even farther apart, but it doesn't help. I hope it's just something wrong with this particular Plus. I'm returning it for a new one because I'm not about to spend $160 on something that doesn't do what it promised!!
Honestly, I think my Echo 2nd Gen has a better speaker, too.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on March 14, 2018
Data:
I am enjoying getting to know Alexa, although she is a bit hard of hearing at times. I have my Echo connected to my Ring doorbell. I thought it would be able to audibly answer my door, but it seems I need to buy the Echo show, for that feature (I did not really want the image, just the voice.
The Ring provides the image, when I use my phone. ). What a disappointment. Also, I have not determined how to get the Echo to make phone calls without buying the Echo connect. I am disappointed that it seems I need to buy a more expensive Echo model and other accessories to get Alexa to really be more helpful to me. Also, Amazon support is not really helpful with learning to use the Echo.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on December 11, 2017
Data: I will start buy saying that I love the sound quality and the color of this model. This is my 3rd Amazon Echo; I love them all and use them every day! For some reason, this particular model sometimes has trouble staying connected to the internet. I have tested this with my other Echo's in the same spot all around the house. The echo dot and original echo will stay connected without a problem, while this one keeps stopping and reconnecting. Thankfully, this does not happen every day. I was also disappointed to learn that the price dropped around $30 within a week of purchase and amazon refused to adjust the price; I had to go through the hassle of returning and re-buying the product. Given that this is an Amazon product, I see this as poor customer service.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on March 22, 2018
Data:
I like the appearance of the unit and the sensitivity of the microphone.
The setup was another story. I found the instructions resulted in me, the user, making assumptions about what was to be done, and it seemed that all my choices were incorrect. This led to an install that should have taken 10-20 minutes, took me two days.
I have worked on computers and accessories for over twenty years, so I am not a novice when it comes to installations of equipment.
I also discovered that without all the accessories (which are quite costly), the Echo is only a glorified Siri box.
Once I have the funds to buy the accessories that control the devices that Alexa can turn on and off, etc., I might be more excited about the product.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on August 12, 2020
Data:
First the positive. Better sound quality than I expected.

Attempted setup using iPad. Echo was not recognizing it. Attempted repeatedly. Went to a chat for help. The help was useless. Worse than poor. Finally figured out I needed to change a WiFi setting via iPad. Never explained by chat representative or in setup guidelines. Found that answer in an obscure post by someone with similar problems. Do amazon gets a “F” in their help.

It now randomly will quit playing amazon music. Or the PBS station I listen to. It’s not the u Ferber or Sufi connection.

So glad I did not pay full price. And amazon help is a joke.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on March 10, 2018
Data:
I was thinking I'd get the same Amazon Echo as the original, but with the "Plus" only meaning built-in hub.

Unfortunately, Amazon has REMOVED the RJ45 Ethernet Jack, so it is Wi-Fi ONLY. I would have paid more for the Ethernet RJ45 Jack back.

I think remving the Ethernet RJ45 jack was was a horrible mistake by Amazon, and I would've paid more for it..... otherwise yes it does usually work.. If and when it an find a channel on my overloaded wifi router.

I think when Amazon realized their mistake on trying to save a buck they came out with the Amazon Ethernet RJ45 adapter... but unfortunately it just barely works if at all, read its reviews and you'll see it's very disappointing too. Amazon should've left it built-in.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on July 16, 2018
Data: Alexa is a decent speaker if that's all you need. She is terrible at most other things. She consistently answers questions that were not asked or says "hmmm I don't know that" for everything else. We've gone back to just using our phones because she can't really look anything up. Pretty much everyone makes fun of me for spending money on this when I had an awesome Bose bluetooth already. I bought her because my mother (who lives alone) uses hers a lot and is happy with it, but we have a full house with kids and I'm less than impressed. I'd never recommend it to anyone except for senior citizens who love alone and need to be able to shout out for help in the event of a fall.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on December 7, 2019
Data: On it’s own, the device works well. However, when it is used in a group with other Echo devices it caused problems. I subscribed to Amazon Music unlimited and made groups for my whole house, upstairs and downstairs. The upstairs group worked find but the whole house and downstairs would cut out after one or two songs or just not play at all. I tested each Echo individually, and they all worked perfectly with Amazon music. Finally, I tried taking individual echos out of the group and found that the Echo Plus was causing the problem. Now all my groups work find. Not sure what the solution is for this one Echo.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on January 10, 2018
Data: This is the first review I have ever done. I own the Amazon Echo, 5 Echo dots, and then I just purchased the Echo Plus. The reason I did it was that I perceived it was an “upgrade” because you no longer need a hub to connect your lights, etc. That is true, however the Echo Plus does not offer the same functionality without a Phillips Hub. Your can’t turn your lights color easily, nor can you set up automations easily. You need the hub to do this (I confirmed this when I called their customer service). Additionally, Alexa does not seem to hear as well as it does with my regular Echo. Overall I am disappointed with this produce.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on January 27, 2018
Data: Alexa is an excellent tool for listening to music, better yet by paying an additional $3.99 per month for a subscription to Amazon Music Unlimited. Alexa voice recognition has much room for improvement. We have not yet used it to initiate orders from Amazon, but suspect it may be error prone until the voice recognition is improved. Echo interfaces with products from other manufacturers, such as Phillips lights, is not user friendly, instructions are not clear, Alexa is fun to use for chats, useful for quick queries on some subjects such as "when do the Celtics (or Bruins or Patriots) next play?" AI learning by Alexa seems to be slow, if at all, but with patience should be expected to provide evolving improvements.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on July 16, 2018
Data:
Pros- plenty loud for a large room with high ceilings.
Cons - the hub doesn’t do anything. It doesn’t work with z wave (as it states), it doesn’t take voice commands for SmartThings, which I had to buy since the hub doesn’t work for z wave.
It also sounds muffled and there is no way to control the EQ. (Not sure if that is on all models, but the Dots we have are clear.
For the money, buy an echo dot or echo (2nd generation). The echo dot takes voice commands for the smart things hub, go figure, and the audio is clear. The dot also seems to hear my voice better and almost at a whisper.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on July 30, 2018
Data:
Still need more AI built into it to interact better. It needs to continue the conversation sometimes if the finding / answer needs to be right. You can't keep stop Alexa and ask again and again. Also, it should be able to access the wikipedia, dictionary in many areas with better and fast access.

Needs to hear us better. Also, we should be able to name it on our own instead calling Alexa or Echo. Price can be reduced a bit (value based) and updates should be auto and daily to improve it. Connectivity to other home equipment can be imrproved as well.

Good product with good sound quality, but needs more AI built in.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on January 26, 2018
Data: Liked the most: Music on demand, weather outside, smart home capabilities. What I was most disappointed in was trying to set up the room to room speaker feature. I needed this so I could communicate upstairs to my handicapped wife. I even bought an extra echo dot to do this. Could not get it set up because my smartphone is not compatable. Read some forums and such and this is not a unique problem. In fact I read there are many such problems with a variety of features. None of these were addressed in the product description. In the computer world I call these "yeah buts". Well it can do this and that and this. Well can it? Yeah, but...............

Date: Reviewed in the United States on January 11, 2019
Data: Both our children got us one for Christmas 2017. Try One at our home in NJ. After a couple weeks it would talk without anyone being around so it was unplugged. The second one was a plus with a light bulb. I wanted to control a lamp like an old fashioned timer would. It did not understand and I do not think the first generation does this. I bought a 5 timer and it works fine. The second Echo started talking without saying Alexa. Now that one is unplugged. Since I do not believe in becoming vunerable to having my home accessable to hackers, I really do not see the need for these products.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on January 30, 2018
Data: Alexa is pretty cool, but not as efficient as we'd hoped. For instance, she says she cannot find our Fire TV stick or any other devices. But if I ask her to play a certain movie it will appear on our TV. Apparently she is able to connect with TV. Also, Alexa is stuck in Mountain time, but we are in CST. Originally she would report the correct time, but somewhere she switched to MST which is annoying. We have tried reprogramming her from all of her/our apps. The Alexa app says she is now reprogrammed to CST zone, but gives the wrong time when we ask for the time. These two items are frustrating and annoying for us.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on September 13, 2018
Data: OK, but makes mistakes and doesn't know some things. I like that it is on when my computer is off. Good for music, notifications and weather. It gets confused sometimes and responds with odd answers. Will not add dollars and cents. Have not tried the hub function yet - I don't have a smart home. Cannot (I think) connect to the computer. Cortana (Windows) is connected to computer and will provide text and images links. I have not explored all functions yet. I think there is a link in an email from Amazon for more detailed descriptions of functionality - haven't been there yet.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on November 21, 2017
Data: I am a first time buyer and don't know anything about the previous models to compare it to. It is an interesting toy, but not one that I must have. As far as being able to converse with it, I find Alexa isn't all that smart. I found it useful to turn on and off lights and to dim them. I also like the skills like playing sounds of rain or crickets, but I find if I am playing one and want to switch to another one I can't because it wants to continue playing what I had on previously. I have the same problem with playlists. The sound from the speakers is very good.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on November 21, 2017
Data:
The plus did not perform as promised. It can not find my Phillip light bulbs or the Go light. And they are sitting all in the same room?
The sound is excellent and this pleases me. But the internal Hub is just not working. I did try to call Tech service for help but the person (for the first time in my experience with the Tech Service) did not seem to grasp the problem or just was not able to figure out what to do.
Right now with Thanksgiving coming up, I'm busy preparing for company. No time to dink with something like this. NOT HAPPY !!

Date: Reviewed in the United States on December 3, 2017
Data:
Works great I just wish the hub had more functionality. Let’s talk about the good first.
Pros
-great sound
-gets very loud
-love you can turn volume up and down on unit
-Picks ups voice slightly better the DOT version
-set up for Phillips hue blub very easy
-Love Routines feature
Cons
-Hub is very limited in options
-setup up with non zigbee products can be difficult
-Bass could be a little better
-I feel like I’m only paying for a sound upgrade
It’s a good product but if the hub is the main reason you want this and it’s not on sale. I would just buy a separate hub.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on January 9, 2018
Data:
I bought it for my parents who were a little resistant at first but now love it. My biggest issue is connecting it to their Philips Hue Bulbs. Originally I could not connect to any of them, and after 2 weeks, I finally got 2 of 3 to connect. I had followed instructions on how to reset the bulbs, and nothing worked for the last bulb. Finally broke down and bought a Hue Bridge, which I found out I could't connect to the Echo.

It's great for asking questions, setting timers, playing music, but the supposed added benefits of the plus, I find to be lacking.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on August 26, 2018
Data: Lo que mas me gusta de este device es que suena espectacular, y ademas, puede programarse con la APP para que suene la misma musica, desde spotify, al mismo tiempo, desde distintos dispositivos Echo. Esto permite armar un sistema de sonido espectacular en mi departamento: pieza, baños, cocina, bar... todo cubierto con un par de Echo Plus y Dots para baños, Me estoy comprando otro adicional, junto con las baterias que lo convierten en remoto. Recomendable, pero no es tan "sharp" como el dot en terminos de Instrucciones. Es un pena que no este en Español, por esto le bajo la clasificaicón.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on November 21, 2017
Data: The Alexa part of this works well, it can hear you from a distance above any music it's playing. However the hub is limited (would like to see Z-Wave) and the ability to chain together events still needs work. More importantly, the speaker - while decent - is underwhelming. Since I didn't plan on using the Zigbee hub, I went with the Sonos. The sound out of a Sonos w/Alexa is FAR superior. However if you're just interested in a good speaker, having a smart hub to control lights and switches, and use Alexa, this is a great value.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on January 9, 2018
Data: This is just "okay". I expected it to be able to answer questions like Google or Siri but it can't. It also won't adjust the volume with voice control when playing music . You have to manually turn it up or down. Since I don't have a "smart home", the only benefit I see is to play music. I am returning it & waiting to buy Google's Home Assistant which will suit my needs. Maybe I just got a bum Alexa model..IDK but I am exchanging it for a Dot for my dtr to have in her room to play music.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on March 8, 2018
Data: Had some issues with it not working. Had to call and re do all aspects of the set up. It took almost 3 hours frustration set in. Still learning all it can do. Wish it was more informative with regards to asking simple questions. Always tells me, “I don’t understand the question “ or “I do not know that” just frustrating at times. Love the customer service! They are awesome, even though it took 3 hours of resetting the thing, patients is their strong suit, I told the guy I would have hung up on me a long time ago!

Date: Reviewed in the United States on March 14, 2018
Data: I bought this because it had a controller hub. It is confusing to figure what the controller controls. I feel like I've been had. I was looking to have a music / talk radio source for a kitchen area. It serves that purpose well. I also want to control some light switches. It's confusing what the hub does or if WiFi control is a better way to go. Poor training from Amazon. Amazon come on and help us out....got my free light bulb...but that is not a switch controlling multiple lights.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on February 6, 2018
Data: To be honest I should of bought the regular echo not the plus the hub is pretty worthless when paired with the Alex app basically all you can is turn lights, plugs no real control of color bulbs and stuff if they made a app geared towards the hub it would be okay. I ordered the Wink hub so I Could have full control of my devices with that being said the other functions of this is great nice sound but in my opinion just order the plain echo then use the Wink hub or smarthings hub

Date: Reviewed in the United States on November 16, 2017
Data: If you have the first generation Echo DO NOT BUY THIS ! The speakers are half as loud and there is no bass. The microphones don’t seem to hear me half as well as my first generation. Playing music one 1st generation in my master bedroom and this new 2nd generation in my living room I can hear the 1st generation Echo over the new one. I tell this new Echo to set a timer and the old Echo sets the timer. TERRIBLE ! Dolby Surround put their name behind this ? LOOKS BAD ON DOLBY SURROUND !

Date: Reviewed in the United States on December 7, 2018
Data: Other than the built in smart hub this thing is a let down at every turn. The main reason we love our Echos is Amazon Music. Our first Gen Echo is at least 1/3 louder and sounds way better with no distortion. At max volume the 2nd Gens are nowhere close to as loud. We actually ended up putting this one in our daughters room and put the 1st gen back in the main room because it sounds so much better and louder. I wish I could just buy the originals.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on March 14, 2018
Data:
I still feel these are a bit unnecessary and that the human race is becoming increasingly dependent on technology for the most ridiculous reasons.

But, that being said, I do enjoy the speaker for my music and being able to scream at another female (voice) to turn the light on after a long day of pent up frustration. There's something oddly satisfying about talking down to a piece of technology that's oblivious to your sarcasm and snide remarks, only to answer with, "Sorry, I don't know that one."

Well what do you know, bitch?

Date: Reviewed in the United States on July 20, 2018
Data: I was suppose to get the “free” lightbulb with purchase. It did not come with Echo. Upon reading more carefully, it says to click a box to receive free bulb. 😳 of course I want the free bulb, who wouldn’t? Just a sneaky way for them to get out of having to give so many “ free” bulbs away. Disappointed! I have yet to set up my echo, our first purchase on any alexia device. Debating if we want to keep it. It did come quickly with my prime membership.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on September 13, 2018
Data: Just received my Echo Plus today. Looks good and the sound quality is pretty great however I am pretty disappointed. I bought this with the purpose in mind of having a portable speaker I could easily move from room to room or use on location when shooting clients. I was not aware this unit required constant electricity when I ordered so I will most likely be returning 😔 unless the hubby decides we should just keep it. Oh and the app kinda sucks. Constantly cuts in and out with music.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on April 8, 2019
Data: Don't get me wrong I really like my echo but there are times that she acts really damn stupid. Sometimes she can hear me perfectly fine, even a whisper and then there are times where it seems she ignores or doesn't hear and this gets pretty annoying. Another thing that I would like to say is she still needs upgrading. Most questions you ask her she won't know but hopefully Amazon works on that. Overall it works well with controlling Electronics (sometimes >_<)

Date: Reviewed in the United States on September 2, 2018
Data: The system is ok. But I was disappointed that when I take it to our timeshare for vacation it does not connect to a public network. It works fine on your home network. It says in the instructions it can connect to public network but I have seen a lot of blogs when I researched the problem saying it does not connect at all to public WiFi. A big big minus for Echo. It can’t be that difficult to fix. Get your act together Amazon.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on September 15, 2018
Data: I decided to upgrade after our 2nd Gen Echo was stolen. I like the plus, but I like the sound on the 2nd Gen better. I don't think the Hub is worth the extra cost, at least not that I have found yet. We LOVE the Alexa features and own many echo products. I just wouldn't make this purchase again. I would stick to the 2nd Gen since I feel the speaker quality is just better for the price.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on March 14, 2018
Data: I am disappointed that you can't set an on, off time for the Hue light bulbs with Alexa. It does not act as or replace a hub, which was my impression when I read the description of Alexa Plus. As far I can tell, to get FULL control of the lights, you have to purchase the Hub. Some apps may allow you to have SOME control. I am assuming this is a marketing strategy between Phillips and Amazon. However , I am a fan of Alexa in general.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on January 13, 2018
Data: It's fun but not very smart. I expected way more from her. She doesn't know weather by the hour, can't teach me a language, and has limited music stations. For example, she doesn't have workout music that doesn't include hip hop. However, she is good at question of the day, joke of the day, finding my Pandora stations, and weather....as long as your not asking what hour it's suppose to stop raining, or where the rain breaks are...I have to use my phone for that.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on April 9, 2018
Data: Thanks. In general, it's awful. The only thing I've hear Alexa get right is playing music. But to ask her questions you could google, I always get some obscure answer completely unrelated to what I've asked. She cannot do simple tasks like setting a timer or a reminder, basic things you would expect from AI. Comparing to SIRI, Alexa has failed in comparison. At this point, I have not and do not foresee getting the benefit out of the investment I made on this device.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on May 22, 2018
Data: It's bassy and muddy. Male voices in things like podcasts and audiobooks come out boomy and muffled. There is no ability to control bass or treble. The Alexa stuff is all very useful and fun, but I am disappointed. I had read good reviews of this speaker's sound - and this is supposed to be Amazon's best Echo product - but I will likely be returning it and either hooking an Echo Dot up to my own speakers or purchasing a Sonos One.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on January 8, 2018
Data:
This has been a good device. We have used it to turn on a light, to play music, and get questions answered. The reason for the mid range rating is:
1) there have been searches for questions were the answers were wrong or biased. I expect a search device to give and sort without a bias
2) for music the sound is not the greatest. Where music is a primary feature I expected more
3) it has problems sometimes recognizing Boise requests. Even when spoken clearly

Date: Reviewed in the United States on May 2, 2018
Data: Much better sound than my first gen Echo but not worth the extra cost of the Plus. Echo Plus hub doesn't support scenes unless you have a Hue hub (but then whats the point of the Echo Plus hub). And Echo Plus doesn't support motion sensors. So, after the painful task of moving my Hue bulbs to my Echo Plus from my Hue hub, I will be moving them back to the hub. Wish I could get a refund.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on November 5, 2018
Data:
Every day we have to struggle to reconnect our Echo Plus to the internet. Our Echo stays connected with no problem. We have even had them in the same room, with the Echo Plus disconnecting daily. SO FRUSTRATING!
As a follow up, I am pleased with how quickly Amazon called us to help with our connectivity issues. A refurbished replacement is on the way, so we are hoping to have better luck with it. Stay tuned....no pun intended.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on January 10, 2018
Data:
I really have had a hard time getting this to connect to the Phillips Hue Bulb and the Kasa Smart plug that I ordered with this echo. I've tried to find technical support but there is ZERO help available to trouble shoot. I still cannot use the smart bulb or plug...

Other than the issues getting the echo to connect to my smart devices, this is a really nice unit. I like listening to music with it and getting my daily briefing from Alexa.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on November 8, 2018
Data: I traded in a Bose speaker to get this because it had a built-in hub for my Hue bulbs. Despite the fact that this is supposed to be Amazon's premium speaker, I am completely underwhelmed by the quality of the sound for the price. I have had much better sound from speakers that cost half as much. On a positive note though, the voice recognition works well, and the volume adjustment ring on the tops is nice.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on December 11, 2017
Data: I thought it was a great deal to pre-order the Echo Plus with smart bulb at a discounted price in September and had to wait until October 31 to receive it. I'm still getting used to it and trying different things. The Alexa app is the hardest part. I would have given this 4 or 5 stars if they didn't just reduce the price to $119 with the smart bulb included only 11 days after my return window closed. I won't make that mistake again!

Date: Reviewed in the United States on January 26, 2018
Data: cute, don't like having to say it name every time you ask a question, you ask the weather and you get it but if you have another question you have to say her name. Im use to saying thank you after taking to some one and it off. Not a big thing just a learning curve. In the conversation mode she will not stop. Try several times and keep asking me the same question. Overall I do like it.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2018
Data: I should of known, this is a small speaker with very limited volume which is really only good for one room. Maybe all you shoppers like the ease with which you can access Amazon for purchases but not me. For me, I'm into music that covers a large spectrum with the exception of opera and country. I am impressed with the Echo's seemingly vast reservoir of music on tap but it just can't be played LOUD!

Date: Reviewed in the United States on September 1, 2018
Data: The smart hub only works with Alexa, and does not work with other services like IFTTT. For example, you can't use IFTTT to turn on a light connected to the echo plus hub. A regular echo with a separate zigbee hub would be better value for your money. Also, there doesn't seem to be any support for this device (I've never gotten a response from supper). Speaker is ok but not great. There stars is generous.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on March 1, 2018
Data: Having seen Apple's new entry into this market, I now believe I was premature in purchasing The Echo Plus. It does have a good speaker, but it doesn't access my music on my Mac. I have music that is not included in Amazon Prime. So I have to hook up my other speakers to my Mac to listen to my own music. Also, it's range of connectivity needs to be extended by the App...which also has some valuable services.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on October 7, 2018
Data: It works sometimes. Too often I get, "Gee, I don't know that one." from Alexa. Also, it is an expensive device just to turn off a couple of lights. A friend was keen for me to get this, so I did. I think he had fun installing it for me. I just use my 200 remotes to get to the shows I want to watch. It's faster.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on July 28, 2018
Data: Although this is my second echo device, I am still very disappointed that there is almost no documentation/instructions as to the many functions of the device. I purchased becausse of the sound quality, but only found out it has bluetooth capabilities last night by accident. There needs to be a manual that details all of the functionality of the device. Or at least point out where it can be found...

Date: Reviewed in the United States on January 19, 2018
Data: Overall I like the plus, but I have 5 echos, 4 dots and the plus, one there are not enough wake words, the wake need to be different than the names like Amazon, echo... The TV confuses Amazon and Alexa and they try to deal with the TV. They start babbling, etc. Also the plus is hard off hearing sometimes, chatted with customer service, reset the plus still issues. Otherwise all is well.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on July 27, 2018
Data: Sounds well and we find it useful overall but it can be frustrating when it doesn’t respond or you forget the correct command. “Alexa, turn on the living room lights”. Oops I mean “Alexa turn on the family room lights”. I also never realized I call my couch a sofa some times. Unfortunately my Alexa is confused by my changing names for where I sit.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on January 27, 2018
Data: Voice recognition is pretty good. Not a bad tool to have. Would of been even better if you would be able to dock it where you would like it to be other than has to be plugged in to an outlet which in most cases is in an inconvenient spot for it to have power. Maybe a rechargeable one can be useful as well. Freedom from a wall outlet

Date: Reviewed in the United States on July 28, 2018
Data: I like the list ability and the music I can play. I do not like that I can not create a playlist without using the app and even then Alexa will not play my songs I have to do it through my tablet or phone. I also do not like that Alex can not print again it has to be done through the app.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on January 8, 2018
Data:
Really thought it would be something I'd use more than just to listen to music on. I have no other use for it. Many things I ask it it doesn't even know.(thought it would be "smarter") It has good sound though.
After a year or so of use the volume adjuster on top stopped working properly. Have to use voice or the Alexa app to make adjustments.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on February 15, 2018
Data:
The Echo works great. The built-in hub seems to work good but but unlike the wink hub it there is no options for setting up robots. With the wink hub I can set up robots that when my Arlo camera detects motion it will trigger which ever light I set to come on.
Basically I think it's just the Alexa app that needs some features added.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on July 6, 2018
Data: This is the best Amazon speaker with Alexa in it. But if you’re thinking it’s a good smart hub you’re wrong. Are you can do is connect your smart lights and devices to it and tell Alexa to Turn them on and off. That’s it! You’re better off buying separate hubs so you have more control of your devices.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on April 3, 2018
