Date: Reviewed in the United States on November 2, 2017
Data:
When I saw Amazon had chosen to put a ZigBee hub in an Echo, I was excited. When I saw they were adding easy setup and a wealth of smart home features to the Alexa App, I did not hesitate, I pre-ordered the Echo Plus, and I am glad I did.

First up, is unpacking and configuration. The box seemed difficult to get into, I wasn't sure which side was the top, and if it opened like a jewelry box or not, so I just ripped it open. That was the most complicated part of configuring the Echo Plus. Seriously, you plug it in, the ring does its hypnotic, “you will buy everything on Amazon” dance until the device shows up in your Alexa App. You follow the prompts and tap and go.

The first thing I did after configuring was ask Alexa to play a Bob Dylan radio station. I have a Big Jambox as my around the house and yard speaker. The Jambox is so good, I never looked for another Bluetooth speaker, so it, and my giant Polk RTI A9 towers are my reference for the Echo Plus. I was initially disappointed. Bob sounded like he was playing on my bedside clock/radio, but it was an old track. My go-to test song for audio systems is Finally Woken by Jem. The Echo Plus did an adequate job with the bass. It plays loud, which seems to be how it overcomes its shortcomings. It actually sounds better when I am in an adjoining room. I blame the Bose tweaking. Given time to loosen-up, it will be a good enough speaker, better than the Big Jambox. If someone gets clever and joins a subwoofer to the Echo Plus, maybe through the audio out port, it could be a really good three-way setup. But I didn't buy the Echo Plus for the audio.

I have been a smart home enthusiast since the early 90s. What? Yea, way back in the dark ages a system called X10 did most of what you can do now. You had to set dials on the plugs to assign them to buttons on the remote. You could make scenes by grouping switches to special buttons on the remote and they even had a universal remote that you could train to your TV and VCR. My system had door sensors, a siren, and a dialer to call me if something happened at home. My lights were on timers set through the remote, or dials on the "smart" plugs. It all worked without an internet connection or intrusive account signup.

Fast forward fifteen years and not much changed, so I tried the Piper. A security camera as a hub matched my security focused X10 past, and Z-Wave looked like a successor to X10. The piper has been acceptable, but is retired as a smart home hub as of today.

Next up was the Nest. The “learning when I am home and away” feature had promise. I imagined a world where my smarty-pants thermostat would turn on lights and unlock doors for me when I arrived home. But, the “Works with Nest” never bore fruit. An endless array of devices promised to tell Nest I was home, but not the other way around. When the Nest (after working fine for eight months) put my HVAC into an endless restart mode on the coldest day of the year, I decided the Nest was an idiot and replaced it with my old “smart” thermostats that had worked fine for a decade.

The last four years have seen an endless amount of smart home announcements with promise, but few actual products that didn’t come with lots of baggage. The biggest bag being a dedicated hub, and the carry-on (so to speak) application and dedicated account to control that device. I didn't want to go down that road, so I have waited and watched while my Piper faithfully managed the table lamps I have plugged into the two Z-Wave plugs that came with it. If I had acted on my impulses, I would have at least three hubs and five applications for my “smart” home, and to make it all work together I would need yet-another-account on IFTTT. The DIP switches and dials of X10 were friendly by comparison. (If your $200 smart home product needs a third party service to make it smart, your product is not worth $200).

Back to the Echo Plus. By the time I had removed a Z-Wave plug from a table lamp and screwed in my new Hue bulb, Alexa informed me I had a software update. The Echo Plus rebooted itself and I said, “Alexa, find smart home devices.” Forty seconds later the Hue bulb was working through voice commands given to the new Echo Plus or my Dot in another room.

As an experiment, I moved the bulb to different lamps around the house to see if losing power would force me to set it up again. It did not.

When you configure devices Alexa names them in a simple “light 1”, “light 2” manner. You must change the names in the Alexa application to make them more meaningful. Once you do, Alexa understands the new name.

The Groups and Scenes features are tabs on the same screen with Devices. Once you have a few devices configured, (I recommend doing one at a time so you can name them as you go) you can group them to work with a single command. I don't have to say “Alexa, turn on entry light,” then “Alexa turn on fireplace light,” to light my living room. After making the Living Room group I can say “Alexa turn on the Living Room.”

Routines are on a different screen in the Alexa App. Go to Settings to find it. This was the first hiccup in my experience. I wanted to configure a “bed time” routine, but the lights action said, “turn on” the light and I did not see an obvious way to turn the light off. Turns out, you just tap the light bulb icon to switch the mode to off. Now I am happy. When I say, “Alexa bed time,” I get the current temperature, and my assigned lights turn off. Perfect.

I have seen reviewers complaining that you cannot control color temperature of lights with the Alexa App. Of course the same reviewers practically fell out of their shorts when Alexa skills allowed you to say things like "Alexa, tell Nest to set the temperature to 72." True, you can't do everything the Hue App does, but to get Hue App like control, I would need to add a Hue hub. No, just No. AND, who wants to pay $40 for a light bulb when you can get them $14 (4 dumb LEDs are now $12). Seriously, I paid $19 for my first dumb LED bulb, now I can get two smart bulbs for the same price. If color changing becomes available through the Alexa App later, and I don't need another hub, I will consider a color bulb at that time.

What about thermostats? Well, my thermostats are fifteen years old. They have a weekday and weekend schedule and have never left me in the cold like the Nest did. Because of my Nest experience, I won't buy another “smart” thermostat until I see one available with “Simple setup with Echo Plus.” Ideally one that I don't have to create yet-another-account to adjust the temperature in my home.

And door locks? OK, I am old. I have been using door locks with ten-key pads on them since I was a teenager. They are a great alternative to carrying a bunch of keys. Especially when it is a long walk back to the workshop with your keys. I don't see the advantage of having to pull out my phone to unlock a door. If you are at all security conscience then you would need two smart locks for each door, one for the dead-bolt and one for the door knob (I have not seen an integrated unit yet, if there is one, let me know because I would be interested.) Maybe when a smart door unlocks and opens for me as I approach I will be more excited.

And cameras? I don't have any, yet. The Piper detects motion and monitors my doors with Z-Wave sensors. It records to the cloud when an alarm has been tripped. It does not require a paid subscription. I will keep it for my security system until I see a better alternative. I have looked at Arlo because I think the best value comes with exterior cameras, but I am concerned with their slow response times. I can imagine ZigBee door sensors triggering alerts and recordings on a linked camera. That would be a less intrusive option than something recording 24/7.

This is my Smart Home Mantra going forward: A single application to control all my devices, no more hubs, and the ability to use a voice command to configure my new devices. For me, when it comes to the smart home platform, Amazon has a winner on its hands with the Echo Plus. We know from the original Echo experience that Amazon will be aggressive in pushing new features to the Alexa App. I look forward to those updates and the future purchases those updates will enable.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on May 21, 2024
Data: Ah, the Echo Plus with built-in Hub, 1st Generation—White. A relic from a simpler time when Alexa's voice summoned more chaos and less... eye-rolling indifference. It's dependable, sure, and it does its job well enough: controls your smart devices, answers your banal questions, and occasionally plays a tune to drown out the screams. But honestly, does anyone even care anymore? With newer models on the loose, this one's starting to feel like yesterday's carnage. Still, it gets the job done without whining. Four stars for functionality, minus one for the slow, creeping sense of irrelevance.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on January 21, 2018
Data:
This is the first echo product in our household; we got it for Christmas and bought echo dots to go in each room. I love the echo plus. Yes it’s creepy at times, yes Alexa turns on and asks random questions which has my husband and I staring wide eyed talking about Amazon monitoring our household… but she’s so cool! Here are a few things…

Music
- I love this, with Prime we get most music, though some (like Space Jam) is only for purchase.
- Love the playlists (especially classical focus in the morning) but, BUT there should be more options. Some of the playlists only have 5 songs. Also I feel like Alexa should remember what song you left off on so you don’t have to start at the beginning of the play list again.
- I wish they had radio stations for Alexa (not adding a premium spotify account and using their radio stations) I know some local stations have it, but I’d love to have a classical station that can be played continuously, not with the same songs, or a 90s station that doesn’t have the same songs.

Audiobooks/audible
- I love that it connects to my audible account but there’s sometimes still lag in where I left off on the book, either on Alexa or my phone, and then switching back
- You can’t stream your audiobook on a group, just one echo dot or Alexa, this is lame when I’m doing housework I have to still play it on my phone since I can’t listen on a group

Groups
- I love that my entire household is a group, during the holidays (we opened it early sorry dad!) we had holiday music playing on every echo/Alexa and it was awesome
- It sucks you can only have one group. I’d love to have a household group, an upstairs group and a downstairs group; this should be doable with the technology
- We can’t I play my audio book on a group?

Alexa add ons
- I love the Phillips light that is voice controlled, sometimes though Alexa has a hard time hearing the colors we want.. like yellow??
- The dimmable Philips light bulb sometimes flickers when it’s dimmed bellowed 50%
- The plugs we got are a bit bulky, and when we used it with our Christmas tree, we still had to step on the button to turn it on? I think this one might be user error though
- There seems to be a lot of Alexa compatible devices, but I’m having a hard time finding a daylight bulb for my closet, as well as smaller bulbs for some of our lights/fans and lamps.

Random things
- While playing CoD with my sister on speaker phone she can tell my Alexa to play - songs, we have Alexa song wars
- Alexa randomly turns on my phone’s blue tooth, for no reason
- Alexa will randomly tell us we must join a group first

Complaints
- I really liked the cases/covers for the Echo and the Echo dots, but you can’t have one on the plus. This is lame
- The speakers aren’t that great, especially the dots, I have a Bluetooth mini speaker that has more juice than they do
- The white dots come with a black plug… this sucks because I wanted all white in my library and kitchen and the black plug is bulky and noticeable.
- I understand the technology isn’t there yet, but it sucks that you only have three options Alexa, Echo or Computer, we wanted to name ours Alfred.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on November 2, 2017
Data:
Review after 5 days:

Pro: Performs same basic functions as Philips Hue and GE Wink hubs.
Con: Does not perform all functions. Cannot create scenes, cannot set sunrise/sunset timers, and third-party apps that rely on Hue hub will not work once you disconnect that hub.

Pro: Changes color of lights for Hue bulbs with voice. If you only had Hue hub gen. 1, this will be a new feature for you. If you had Hue hub gen. 2, this is not a new feature. This is the primary reason I bought the Echo Plus.
Con: Apple Home Kit will still require Hue hub gen. 2. Apple does not recognize Amazon devices.

Pro: Controls all of my Hue and Wink bulbs and allowed me to disconnect those hubs.
Con: Set up is a huge pain. I might be overly complicated for someone new to Alexa. The bulbs you own will already be paired to their respective hubs. Simply disconnecting the hubs does not allow Echo Plus to take over. You have to reset each bulb. Since Amazon advertises seamless and easy setup, this was a surprise and made me think I was doing something wrong. Setup took 1.75 hours for me. You have to look hard for instructions for your unique devices. The instructions are in the Alexa app.

Pro: Faster response time for GE Wink bulbs. Previously would take up to 15 seconds for these bulbs to respond, now it’s instant just like Hub bulbs have always been.
Con: None, this is a great and unexpected feature. Wink bulbs are much cheaper, and I assumed that’s why they were always slower. Nice that they have instant response now.

Pro: Amazingly strong microphones, will hear a whisper even if it is playing loud music. Echo Dot (or any other Echo) can do this, but Echo Plus’ ability is impressive. Echo Dot did not do a good job of canceling out its own music.
Con: It can hear you over loud music only if Echo is playing this music. Loud ambient sounds or music playing from some other speaker will prevent Alexa from responding to your commands. Amazon is well aware of this issue, and they now sell an Alexa-enabled remote control to use during this situations. I also own the Amazon Dash Wand (for the food delivery service), and it can be used to do the same. Of course, if you have to press a button on these remotes, then it’s no longer truly voice activated.

Pro: Multi-room music plays in sync if you have multiple Echo devices. It also creates a home intercom system with the “drop in” feature.
Con: None, this is a cool thing. But these functions are available on all Echo devices, including the Dot that is 1/3 the price.

Pro: If you order now, Amazon is giving you a free Philips Hue bulb.
Con: Even though it’s free, it’s an ugly, cheap-looking bulb. It’s not sleek glass like my other Hue bulbs. It’s frosted plastic. But then again, it’s FREE. You have to make sure the version you are ordering comes with the bulb. Both versions are the same price, and you might accidentally order the wrong one without the bulb.

Conclusion: Terribly complicated set up. Expensive device that does the same as cheaper Echo Dot with the exception of the internal hub. The internal hub will replace some features of your ZigBee-enabled smart home devices, but will not give the full range of features you’re used to with their native hubs. Subjectively, I think the device is ugly. The other Echo products have more pleasing proportions.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on January 5, 2018
Data:
I’ve had this product for over a month now. As speakers go the Echo Plus is fine, if your looking for good sounding background music. If you want/prefer or need a bigger booming sound you need to look at the Sonos One or consider connecting a separate powered speaker to an Echo Dot (while the Echo Plus does have an aux out jack, using the Dot with an external speaker is more economical). I also have a first Gen Echo so utilizing the new multi-room play capability to play the same music in different rooms is a nice feature. The sound from Gen 1 Echo and Echo Plus is slightly different but not enough to get excited about and/or say that one is better than the other. Like I indicted above if your looking for dance hall sound look elsewhere. One thing you should understand is multi-room streaming does not apply to Bluetooth or your own music (since Amazon is discontinuing the ability to up load your own music to Prime Music). Multi-room is limited to Prime Music and services like Pandora and Spotify.

I selected the Echo Plus over the Gen 2 Echo because of it’s built in Zigbee Hub. I had a few home automation requirements (mostly lighting) I thought the Plus could handle. I didn’t want or need a Hub to handle thermostats, security, locks, scene lighting, etc, etc. And I didn’t want to deal with yet “another” App on my iPhone to handle a Wink, SmartThings or Hue hub. Currently, I have two GE Zigbee wall switch dimmers and two Philips Hue smart bulbs connected to the Alexa Plus. All paired without a problem and all are following the on/off and dimming routines setup in the Alexa App. Those comfortable working with simple electrical DIY will find the GE wired dimmers easy to install (they do however require a connection to the white neutral wire, which may not be available in some older homes). One oddity associated with the Philips smart bulbs is they “pop” on at 100% brightness after a power outage once power is restored. This does not happen with the GE dimmers.

The biggest issue I have with the Echo Plus is the Alexa App. The Alexa App “routines” interface is woefully simple and in dire need of improvement. It’s impossible to keep track of, or group, the various times and brightness levels associated with each smart device. I can’t imagine how confusing it would be with a whole house full of smart switches and smart bulbs. It also lacks a dusk to dawn option. The App is so bad I’m reconsidering my resistance to having yet another App on my phone, to interface with a either a Wink or SmartThings hub. From what I’ve read their Apps are more advanced and robust when dealing with smarthome devices. At this point, I’ll give Amazon some time to update the Alexa App. If that doesn’t happen in the next few months, I’ll begin looking for a different hub. Todate, all the smart stuff I’ve installed will work with either Wink or SmartThings. If I switch, I’ll simply relegate the Echo Plus to a speaker only function.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on November 3, 2017
Data:
I have an original Echo gen 1 that has been working fine for a couple of years now. I am not sure why some people are saying that the audio is worse. I think it is better and most certainly better than the Echo Dot.
The microphone also seems more sensitive and better able to pickup your voice even while it is playing music loudly.

I got this to see if it could be an all in one solution as I currently am also running a Wink Hub 2. I wanted to see if I could just use Alexa and the Alexa app on my iPhone to control everything in the house which includes bulbs, door locks, egg minder (yes I do use it for keeping up with our own chickens eggs and which are the freshest ones). I want to set up scenes and schedules to automate more lights. So far I haven't yet got it to be an all in one. Alexa did not detect any of devices on the Wink Hub. I think there will be more than just asking Alexa to "discover new devices".

With Wink now offering home security monitoring at a low rate things are really evolving in the smart home market. There are so many companies vying for the space. Nest also has a new security system out. Ring doorbell, all the major door lock companies, thermostats, lights, etc... I really think it will be between the big players to see who wins out for me. Apple with Homekit, Amazon with Alex or Google. So far I think Amazon is far ahead of the competition. I think this echo plus just needs some time to really shine. Give it a few software updates and it's upgraded features will be more clear and present.

I am going to keep playing with this Echo Plus. I think it will prove to be a good upgrade in time.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on November 12, 2017
Data:
I ordered the echo plus to go along with the original echo. I decided upon the plus because I use a lot of Philips Hue lights in the home and thought it would be convenient to have the hub. This works just like the original echo, but with better sound and it quickly and easily discovers your devices.

After setting it up, however, I began to have a ton of problems with my lights/groups not working, etc. After contacting customer service, I was told that I should have gotten the Echo Second generation because the plus can not work with the Phillips Hue Hub (which I still wanted to use since it has more features than the echo plus hub). I also had a list of lights in the Alexa App that I disabled, but could not "forget" within the app and it showed I had over 200 lights connected..which I did not (very frustrating and it became a big mess).

During all of this, I was contacted by another rep who had a higher level of understanding of how the Echo Plus works. In short, you CAN use this with the Phillips Hue Hub, you just can't connect your lights to both hubs. The error was in my set up; not the device itself. The representative walked me through the set up process again and also told me about the web based version of the original Alexa app, which allowed me to forget the 200 disabled lights in my app (just Google Alexa Web App)!

In the end, the product is great. It easily connects, has great sound, and you can also connect your phone via bluetooth to play music or podcasts. I am going to exchange it for the second generation, however, because it will save money as I do not want to use the hub.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on November 3, 2017
Data:
[please see update below original review]

I bought the original Echo when it was first available for pre-order and have loved it. No issues. The opposite is the case with Echo Plus.

Doesn't understand me half the time.
Intermittent success using the remote.
Tried multiple times setting up groups to play music simultaneously in different rooms using it with my 2 echo dots and original Echo. Echo Plus responds by doing nothing, or playing a random song or stations, and nothing on the other units in the group.

I really hate returning things, but unless there are fixes in updates between now and the end of the return period, that's what I'll be doing. Seriously disappointed. Oh, and I called Amazon "help" so-called, and I knew more about how it works than the person I wasted 15 minutes on the phone with. It was a surreal convo.
= = =
UPDATE: This morning I got a call from Anthony, from Amazon customer service. First, I was blown away that they would call me to address my issues with Echo Plus. Second, he was knowledgeable, and in no hurry. While it remains to be seen whether every issue with EP is fixed, the problem with Groups was.

It turns out that Alexa didn't like the name I gave my group, it was that simple. My original Echo is black, my EP is white, so I called the group "Black And White". Suggestion: When setting up your groups, go with one of the suggested generic names--bedroom, living room, etc. Echo calls them "Common Names". I called mine "Backyard", even though my backyard isn't involved.

Regarding Alexa often not understanding me on the EP, Anthony suggested that I try switching from British english to American english. I'm going to try that, although I have used British english on my original Echo with no issues.

So, I've upgraded my review to 4 stars, and when and if all issues are resolved I'll be coming back to make it 5. Amazon support definitely gets 5 stars. Even though my first call was a disaster, the way they followed up was remarkable, and that's the important thing. Seriously impressed. Thank you, Anthony!

Date: Reviewed in the United States on February 12, 2018
Data: I really enjoy it but i have yet to connect my smart home devices and there are times it doesnt understand me, or i have to repeat myself multiple times . Other instances there are no answers for specific questions and alexa doesnt understand / speak spanish which is important as my inlaws family mainly speaks nothing but spanish and understands very little english. I wish that there were an option to have it speak / comprehend spanish as it would help. I do find it very useful for my kids and home life . There are skills that can be applied that make them excited to learn and get ready in the morning , alexa can set multiple timers for when im cooking which is really useful and makes my life a million times easier. Date: Reviewed in the United States on July 29, 2018
Data: I love everything about it. I love that the echo plus turns on and off my light. It can also dim them with voice commands. I also like listening to my kindle books even the ones that I didn’t purchased audibles for. I like that it can play my music from Amazon music, pandora, tunein, I heart radio and Spotify. Echo can even play my local radio station. I love that the echo is connected to my TiVo Bolt. This allows TiVo to pause, stop and play whatever I want with a simple voice command. I love that I can reorder items that I purchased on Amazon and that the echo plus notifies me when my order is mailed, when it will be delivered and when the package has been delivered. The only three dislikes that I have is that if you’re up too close or to far the echo doesn’t respond. So I think they need to improve the microphone. And I wish the speaker was better. The speakers are okay but could be improved. Also I have the echo dot and it never has given me any problems with the internet. Well the other day I received a Red Light Right on my Echo Plus. This error was Sorry I’m having trouble understanding you please try again later. After research online I learned it was a problem connecting to my internet. And it was easy to find this out. And I found it odd that my dot wasn’t having this problem even though they are connected to the same network.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on July 21, 2018
Data: I got it to try side by side with the Echo originale. They are essentially the same in dimension, weight and the woofer is the same save for the smaller tweeter point up instead of down and the built in hub. As many folks already pointed out, the hub is not a direct replacement for the Philips Hue, Z wave or anything else. It provides a sub set of features available from the stand alone hub and you ended up losing functionality that you took for granted on the dedicated hub. For me, the voice recognition and music play capability is the same, the original Echo may have an edge on the volume department due to larger speakers. The new Echo plus is priced lower than the original Echo with the built in hub but I don't really need the hub with less functionality. In addition, I don't think that Amazon will have software updates for this hub as other dedicated hub would have so bugs could end up never fixed. My Philips hub gets software update probably once every couple months and it keeps up with the changes in the new bulbs FW and they fixes bugs. Net net for me, this Echo does not do anything more than the original Echo and sound quality is not as good. With the original Echo available as refurbished I would check that out first before considering this or the new Echo which is clearly inferior to both of these.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on November 23, 2017
Data: I bought the echo plus for the hub to control lights for now. It often freezes, doesnt complete the task even though it says it did and there is a problem wirh its spatial function with another echo dot I have. It thinks I'm closer to the dot even though Im standing right near the echo plus which is 10 feet away from the dot. I love the music groups as I am able to stream music to all three of my echos when im working around the house. Nice feature but a bit quirky. I love the list feature as I never forget anything at the market anymore or buy things I already have. I also love the alarm and reminder feature. I'll never use a regular alarm clock again, YEAH!. For some families the intercom feature is great, No more yelling to the kids unless it makes you fell better or more important. I also love the light control. I never have to fumble for the lamp switch while in bed and was able to move the lamp off the night stand. Now I can turn them on and off and dim them with my voice.When your older with several trips to the bathroom at night youll really appreciate it. At this point I am so dependent on my 3 echos that I would never be without them. Keep the updates coming Amazon! Keep in mind that you need the echo plus to turn lights on and off.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on November 22, 2017
Data: I really like the echo plus. It does almost everything I wanted to do with one major exception. I haven't fully set it up yet, but I would like the Echo plus to be able to control a Logitech Harmony remote which in turn would control my Fire TV. I have received conflicting reports on this both from Amazon and Logitech. Some say the Echo plus will control the Logitech Harmony. While others say that the Echo plus will control a Harmony remote but not fully enough to control the Fire TV in its entirety. I am a handicap veteran (quadriplegic) who has no use of my arms or hands. In order to operate the equipment in my room, I require total voice control for everything. My current environmental control unit controls most of the equipment in my room with the exception of the Amazon Fire TV. I was hoping I have the Echo plus in combination with the Harmony remote would allow me to operate my Fire TV with just my voice. I am not sure this is going to work, but I'm going to try it anyways. Maybe in the future Amazon and Logitech will work out the bugs and kinks with being able to control the Fire TV with an Echo plus fully using the Harmony remote. If anyone Amazon as a response to this I would appreciate hearing from you. Thank you.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on January 29, 2018
Data:
Overall it's a great product I only see getting better. I'm not an audiophile but we love the sound quality for background music. We use Amazon music with it which is pretty easy self-explanatory and has a wide variety of options. It's pretty entertaining at times and its good for things like reading audible books, controlling the lights, and telling me the weather in the morning.

A few complaints
1. We have two of these and although they are supposed to work together so only the closest one responds, they would usually both respond. In fact, even if we were across the apartment from one, it was like one would signal the other and they'd both respond. We had to give one a different wake word. Now we run around talking to Alexa, Echo, and Siri when we're home and it gets a little stupid.
2. Fix the volume situation. Add a button or do something. I shouldn't have to spend 45 seconds waking Alexa and requesting incremental adjustments over and over again until it gets to the desired level. Let me give it a percentage or something.
(update: my girlfriend discovered you can tell it to go to volume 1-10 instead of telling it volume up or down over and over again)
3. Fix the App. It's cluttered and confusing and only half works.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on December 12, 2017
Data:
This is a great device that began my path to a smart home. I was able to easily set this up and the philips hue light it came with alongside the tp link power outlet was compatible with this and no hub was required (perhaps due to this device being the only Amazon device with a built in smart-hub)

PROS
-Easy Set-Up
-Compatibility with other devices, doesn't need philips smart bridge for standard dimming light
-Volume can extend to another room easily!
-Now I can watch Amazon Prime Instant Video AND Hulu without my remote cause of this communicating with my Fire TV stick

CONS
-Not all questions will be answered
-Conversations can not have follow up questions like Google Home so conversations don't flow as well in comparison
-Tries to make you sign up for Amazon Music and Amazon Audible and other Amazon services a lot

Final Verdict
If you want to jump into the modern smart home world, this will do the job! Sound is great, can learn skills you give it such as finding your keys (assuming you have the Tile and Tile Skill activated) and is a great device to impress new guests that have never been exposed to Smart Devices

Date: Reviewed in the United States on November 22, 2017
Data: I love Amazon Echo and have been a loyal customer since it was first introduced. I quickly interfaced it with my Wink hub to control the lights in my home. The idea of the Echo Plus with its built in hub that would allow me to eliminate the Wink hub was very appealing, so I preordered the Plus when it was first announced. For the most part it works well in controlling my lights, but naming devices has been something of a problem. It lets me use the old names for some devices, but not others. My husband spent some time on the phone with tech support, but they weren't able to resolve the issue. We continue to pick away at renaming devices, sometimes we can do it successfully and other times not. In the meantime we have given the problem devices new names, which I consider a less than satisfactory resolution. I'm confident that we'll eventually get it resolved, but it's frustrating when I use the old name and Alexa tells me "this device is disabled; please re-enable it to control it." We haven't figured out yet where or how to re-enable it.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on November 11, 2017
Data:
So I bought the echo plus with the hue bulb, boy was I disappointed in both my purchase and with Amazon. There was nothing I read that said to make the hue bulb work that you also have buy the hue bridge which is another $59.97 or if you buy it with 2 more bulbs it is $69.97. I had always thought that Amazon was above playing those type of games.

I already had an echo dot and had it synced with my Bose for music and I already have an echo dot in my bedroom. From everything I have read now all I needed to do was buy a hue bridge and sync that with the dot and I would than be able to schedule my lights. Also when I went to sign in to the Hue app it asked me if I wanted to signed in with my google account, WHAT! where did that come from, if I had wanted to signed in with my google account I would have bought Googles version of echo.

Also if you have a Vivint alarm system the echo and echo plus connect in the same way, both echos will only lock your front door.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on August 9, 2018
Data:
Love my Echo!!! The built in hub works great and easily connected with the light bulb we purchased with it. And I would now be lost without being able to shout out "Alexa, add <blank> to my shopping list> and then simply pull up my shopping list in the store!!! I bought this as a gift for my husband and asked him "Not sure why you want one but ok". Now, I'm hooked!!

However, she doesn't seem very "smart" when asking her regular Google type questions--she seems to come back with "I don't know" type of answers way too often. Ask our phones the same things and it will pull right up. So, some work to do there.

Also some warning that it was having issues would be great. The timer stopped working recently and I didn't know it. I was using it while cooking, so that wasn't good. She confirmed she set the timer but nothing was actually set. When I unplugged it/plugged it back in, all was well but I would have expected it would have told me it couldn't set the timer.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on February 19, 2018
Data:
I put this review as four stars only because there is slight room for improvement on sound, but honestly, I'm nitpicking and this thing is amazing. The built in Zigbee hub was key for me since I run multiple Philips Hue bulbs in the home. This saved the need for a separate Philips Hue bridge for me. Before you ask, "but doesn't the Hue bridge do more?" - sure it does. You can probably pick a color with a color wheel as well as have your music drive the light colors. However, for the rest of us who do not need that level of light control (I'm not a DJ!), the Echo Plus gets the job done. There are 20 different colors to choose from including five different whites. Saying, "Alexa, turn the bulb color red" works flawlessly and it is awesome that all Hue bulbs, color changing or not, are dimmable by Alexa by saying, "Alexa, dim the light to 20%".

The sound is great from this, the home automation works well, and we love having the Echo Plus in the home.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on June 9, 2018
Data: it is a great instrument in regards to smart home and automation. Very good speaker sound quality and its functionality seems to be expanding. It has couple of areas where it can use improvement: customizing its name so that not only can we call it whatever we like, but also reduce the risk of inadvertent activation, conversation recording and sending it to another person without our knowledge. Second, I don't like to ask Alexa to ask another system to do something, such as Alexa ask Bose to play station one etc. It would be nice to say Alexa play music on Bose or whatever system you have. Third, it would be nice if it can be customized to a specific number of voices only. Thank God Alexa is a machine or my four year old would have had it pull all its hair out and run naked across the highway. It is a non stop Alexa do this or Alexa do that. It gets even livelier when my 7 year joins in on the fun and start fighting with each other through Alexa.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on November 21, 2017
Data: I’m really happy with the echo plus. Connecting to smart bulbs was easy and I even connect to TV via the longitude smart hub. The only thing I was a bit confused about is why aren’t all the skills automatically on installed? This would have made it even better. The microphones are good as it can hear me over music playing or people talking. The speaker sound quality is decent; not great. Also, the commands have to be spoken pretty precisely otherwise Alexa will have trouble processing that request. For example, if you name your bedroom lamp a lamp but you say turn on the bedroom light, Alexa will have trouble with it. In addition, a software update needs to enable you to delete old devices. There’s no way to do that now as you can only disable it which also cause Alexa to say “that device is disabled” mistaking it for another device. These are minor issues and can probably be fix with a software update. Overall, I am very happy with Echo plus. I also purchased a Dot for my bedroom.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on September 10, 2018
Data:
This thing works great I was a little disappointed in the speaker, although I think that has more to do with the acoustics of the house and not the speaker its self but thats not why I took a star away. I took a star away because it is so sensitive to hearing its name its kind of annoying, especially when you are listening to music or a book and she interrupts to ask you what you meant. Seriously if a word on the song sounds remotely like her name she interrupts. If your talking on the phone through her and mention amazon she asks me what I want to buy.

I also wish there was a way to put a lock/ keyword/ phrase on her so my kids can't ask her to order more cookies and other random things. I know I could turn that feature off but I like the convience of it. I have a tap, 2 dots, and the echo so its not annoying enough to stop me, but still.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on July 30, 2018
Data:
This is very hard to review because I am part of the problem.

I am 75 and got it so my dog would have distracting noise when I am not home.
I am computer literate, iTunes literate, Amazon literate, as well as countless other programs, but am apparently a dunce when it comes to talking to Alexa. I think I heard her sigh in exasperation.

I tried to create a playlist of songs I like only to have it ignored. I am learning workarounds but they are mediocre, at best...and, as yet do not include a personal playlist.

I have scoured the beginners section but the beginners it addresses are far more advanced in basic Alexa than am I.
So far, I like what I have been able to use but I'd like it a lot more if I could configure it to my needs, rather than accepting the Amazon/Alexa default.

Karen

Date: Reviewed in the United States on October 19, 2018
Data:
UPDATE 10/20/2018; Amazon has contacted me regarding this issue and we are in the process of troubleshooting my Echo Plus unit. It seems there is a bit of a lag in the timing of resuming show titles after pausing. I will be getting a follow-up call Tuesday for any updates regarding operation issues.

++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++
Many times I have used echo to control my Netflix experience. It now seems that with every single update and ‘what else can Alexa do’, more of the features that I used are no longer available. I think it’s silly that I once was able to control my Netflix yet now it’s a feature ‘she’ doesn’t know how to do. Tsk tsk on you Amazon for taking away features that people use most, and applying it to your proprietary services like the lack luster prime video. This will be the last echo unit I will buy.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on August 28, 2018
Data: This is my 2nd Echo device. I had a really good Amazon customer service experience with Tim, who swapped out the smaller Echo device I didn’t care for with this device, it was a definite improvement. This device has good speakers, they’re just not quite a good as the original Echo device I got 2 years ago. I understand they have different speakers than the old device, and I mentioned that there is a market for the higher quality speakers in the Echo device, they just need to market it. The reason I won’t give it 5 stars is my ongoing issue with Echo, I play music all day and it continues to drop the signal throughout the day. I have given up trying everything Amazon Customer Service suggests to fix it, as no matter what I do, the signal drops. Besides that frustration, I would buy another.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on September 28, 2018
Data:
Pretty nice to be able to walk into the room and activate my sonos system, get the news, set timers, etc. Speaker quality is OK, but not the best for listening to music. I use a sonos system and Alexa connects with it, so that is nice.

Setup was a pain. It was a speaker I won in the US and I am a Canadian so I had to do a bunch of work arounds to get it setup. (Changed my Amazon address to a US one, setup as a US resident and then after setting up I had to change everything back). I'm not sure if this is because it was a unit meant to be sold in the US? Anyways, it wasn't as easy as it could have been and if it was my parents trying to set it up they wouldn't have been able to.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on July 30, 2018
Data:
We got this mainly for our son who is currently vision impaired ! it has many good things and setup was fairly easy once I did the first one but they should be easier to setup and come loaded with more stuff ! it should do Text messages to friends easier without them having to download something for it to work and it should link with email and also them common social media like facebook and twitter and others !
the whole purpose was to get him back connected to the Web by voice so he wouldn't feel left out and isolated ! they should also have a tech support phone number to call or a way to do direct help to the Echo so tech support can help setup the device ! I had to get a friend whos an IT guy to come help me setup

Date: Reviewed in the United States on November 21, 2017
Data: This is my first purchase of an AI device with speaker and hub. First, the sound is certainly good enough for listening and with Alexa finding songs is really a breeze.I had an issue with the Phillips hue light bulb. Amazon overnighted me a replacement. Hooking up lights is really easy. I am discovering new things to do with my device every day. It's nice to play music and have it shut off whenever you want when you go to bed at night. I think think the AI portion and some of the skills that are made for it help to keep my memory sharp. I am hoping they expand more games and skills to enhance that. I will do an update on this and if Alexa's knowledge base grows as I think it will I would give it five stars. Certainly, worth the money, it's a lot of fun too!

Date: Reviewed in the United States on November 20, 2018
Data: We purchased the Echo Plus after having the dot for several months and wishing that we had a better speaker. We thought it was going to seamlessly control our Hue lights but realistically it can only turn them on and off or change the brightness. The reason we have hue lights is to change the colors which currently Alexa can not do but there is an app called Stringify that I have been using to also program the lights for color and it also works well with Alexa. Hoping to add more Echo products to our home and also hoping that some day they give the users the option to name each device (sometimes both devices hear Alexa and it will play on the dot instead so we have changed it to be named Echo).

Date: Reviewed in the United States on November 21, 2017
Data: I absolutely love my Echo Plus! Since I received it I've installed Phillips Hue lights, Leviton switches and smart sockets to control all sorts of lighting. So why four stars? I was really disappointed after owning my Echo for a week only to have it sporadically pause while playing Amazon Unlimited. About 3 or 4 in the afternoon, the music would suddenly stop for up to 15 seconds and then resume where it left off. This would continue for several hours every day. When I switched to using Pandora I had no problems. My next-door neighbor has no problem with Amazon Unlimited On his Echo Plus. He uses FIOS while I use Comcast. So, is it Echo Plus, the network or the music service? I really don't know. But still, I would highly recommend the Echo Plus.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on December 15, 2017
Data:
This Echo Plus is very fun to use. It works great as a digital assistant, an alarm clock, and a music player. The high and mid tones are clear and very good sounds; however, it's a little weak on the low tones (bass). The microphone is very sensitive and it can pick up my voice from across the room without me shouting, even when it's playing music. The Zigbee hub works every well with the included Philips Hue White LED bulb; however, I am having problem linking Samsung Motion Sensor to it, even though the Samsung sensor said Zigbee certified. This issue and the lacking bass are the reason I took out one star for this rating.
I have both Google Home and this Echo Plus, and the microphone on this Echo Plus works much better than the one on Google Home.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on January 9, 2018
Data: 4 instead of 5 because ==> I am sharing prime and I am not the main member thus I do not get the prime music on my account. However, Echo DOES allow me to switch accounts to get the music. Since I can get the this legitimately why does Amazon make me take the extra steps? Can't the software be smart enough to allow this without switching accounts? Might seem petty but if we forget to switch back, most things don't work such as controlled lights, controlled outlets, skills etc... I bet this would also save a lot of calls with issues to Amazon. I know I took up at least an hour of their time figuring this out (not to mention days of my time. It could be such an easy customer sat resolution.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on July 3, 2018
Data:
Was debating between a 4 and a 5 star review. The one challenge with the hub is that Phillips has added functionality that only works with their hub. Basic functionality works with this unit, but now I need two apps to set everything how I want it instead of one, which has caused some user issues. It's woken up a couple times without the trigger word, which I find highly unsettling. We have minor issues with it not always picking up what we say correctly, but it's usually just one or two repeats if that happens.

The speaker is great quality and easily covers the kitchen/living room. The sleek design is not obtrusive. My girlfriend has had fun interacting with it and we've had entertaining conversations with it.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on November 21, 2017
Data: Sound is great and love being able to just ask for a song and it automatically plays it, along with any other music then by the artist. Problem is with using the HUE lighting system with it. If you attempt to use it with the HUE bulbs, it works, build disconnects you from being able to manually use with the HUE or Home Kits apps. Amazon brags on how if the power is shut off it retains whatever info was programmed in pertaining to the lights. Problem is if you want to remove any lights. It only lets you disable them from system, but it still retains the info. So if you reuse the bulb in another area, it shows it twice and so on. You can't just clear everything from memory and start over.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on November 21, 2017
Data: Had it for a few weeks now and for the most part I like it, we now have some smart bulbs ( mostly because we rent ) a smart switch would be the better option for lights. Alexa understands us most of the time, not all the time. Repeat and she gets it. I wish there was more documentation about what will and wont work with this device. With the hub built in I want to add smart alarm and cameras but at the moment the information is scetchy what will and wont work. I use for music and she can play amazon music and we use for our SiriusXM account. Works well and the speakers are clear. I will be getting some dots to go with it for the kids rooms.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on January 29, 2018
Data: This is a great device with more potential than I will be using. Received the LED bulb with my purchase and placed it in a floor lamp and Alexa will turn it on to various brightness with my voice. It also has excellent sound, listen to Pandora radio, and you can move it wherever you want. I have not installed them yet, but I purchased a set of LED strip lights for under my cabinets in the kitchen that also work with Alexa. I have found that Alexa will hear you best in close vicinity or you may find yourself raising your voice in order for her to understand you, say with a TV on in the background. This is the only reason I did not give it 5 stars.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on September 2, 2018
Data: Over all an excellent device. Great sound quality and alexa makes using this device relatively simple. There was a brief sound glitch via bluetooth with my Samsung Galaxy S8. Whenever I click a key or open an app the sound on the echo stops for about a second then continues. This glitch happened the first day and hasn't done it since, I assume an update fixed it. Alexa responds well as long as the device is on a smooth surface without any noise generating devices near her (i.e. dont have her on the floor or counter next to a desk fan or you will have to yell at her). Aside from the brief bluetooth glitch this product is great and I would highly recommend it!

Date: Reviewed in the United States on January 25, 2018
Data: This is one of those products that using it makes you want to use it more. The smart home features and the drop in feature let you stay connected to your entire household. But one thing for me that you never hear about is the hands free messaging. So why is that so important? I live in a secluded area with no neighbors. If I were to fall in my house and not have my phone around me all I have to do is shout out to Alexa to text my husband or make a call. I am not so old that I need a fallen and I can’t get up device. But this gives me the security that I need if I were to fall or get injured. Great piece of mind for me.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on March 1, 2018
Data: It does a lot, very smart when you need an answer to a question. I also love the fact that when I watch a Seahawks game I can have Alexa tune in to the radio station of the game and listen to our home grown announcers, Steve Rabel and Warren Moon.(quick note- you need to pause the TV for one second to be in tune perfectly with the radio- so that the game play matches the call). The only drawback is I thought it would be louder for when I want to listen to music. The online App to add music, etc is somewhat frustrating. I haven't used the hub portion of it yet (light bulbs,etc) but I will in time. Overall I enjoy it a lot!

Date: Reviewed in the United States on August 3, 2018
Data: Alexa’s voice recognition and “understanding” are hit and miss. The Alexa app for my iPhone just quits regularly. I have to relaunch it when it quits. Speaker quality for music is +/-. The echo plus hub only supports some of my WIFI Smart devices. It does not support GE and Lutron. GE makes one of the few 3-way smart dimmers and Lutron makes the only smart light switch that works without a neutral wire. So I have an echo plus and two more hubs, one for Lutron and one for GE. Depending on the Smart Devices you need, you may need multiple hubs. Echo plus will not be your entire solution. Buyer beware.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on January 17, 2018
Data:
It works ok just like everything it could be better not as loud as I was hoping. My biggest complaint is that you have to really think about how to word what you ask her. Another big thing for me is with the music I pay for the Amazon music and some of the songs I downloaded from Amazons rime music she says she can't find them when I ask her to play them
But with that said it is a good product anyone's going to find something the can complain about
So if u buy it you will be happy with it I had the Google home and returned it to get this and I like this one a lot more

Date: Reviewed in the United States on April 20, 2018
Data:
Works like a charm and has nice loud speakers. The only issue is when the music is playing at a certain level, it sometimes has trouble hearing the wake word.

We have 3 echo dots connected to it and have created multiple groups for playing music in specific rooms (family music unlimited subscription is a must if you want to play different music in different groups/rooms. I just wish you could have a unit associated to more than one group.

Right now we have 2 echo dots in upstairs kids room with the wake word disabled. We use it for night time music, making announcements for when they are upstairs, etc. The whole setup is amazing.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on September 4, 2018
Data:
I recently purchased this unit to augment my home. It has already given me the ability to interface with my security cameras, thermostat, and television. Not to mention that the entire family isn't constantly fighting for use of the same Echo device.

The speakers are also significantly better. The aren't the best speakers I've ever heard, but they are plenty loud for everybody to be able to hear in my 2000+ sqr. ft. home. The microphone is also very good and can pick up a wake word from nearly anywhere in the house if you raise your voice.

Complaints include issues with using the right commands and pausing while I try to formulate the right command.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on February 18, 2019
Data: I finally hooked it up after several months ... Delay was due to No/Minimal printed instruction booklet. Sorry, you guys at Amazon, we’re not all techies that like to figure stuff out on our own! FYI - My Microsoft Tablet did not come with any printed instructions, either. I suppose it must be some cost cutting trend, or a plot to keep the "older generation" dependent on our younger "geek friends" to do stuff for us. The funniest thing with my new ECHO was one night, while I was watching/listening to Steven Colbert on my laptop and he said “Alexa” something or other, and my Echo on my nightstand suddenly lit up and responded!

Date: Reviewed in the United States on January 9, 2020
Data: I got this for a Christmas gift for my home, but this was when all of the listening in to your conversations issues came out. It sat in the box on my dresser for 2 years. I just installed it in my operating room and it works great. Great sound considering one speaker and not great room acoustics. Hands free, so no problem changing music, checking time, weather, answering phone while scrubbed in. Amazon can listen to the beep beep beep of the heart monitor all they want

Date: Reviewed in the United States on August 8, 2018
Data:
I liked the ease of learning the devices.
I was unable to change the names of the devices - all I have is 8 dimmers. Alexa calls them: first light, second light etc.... in order to change the names, I was told to download the dimmers app (GE zigbee) which I did but I was unable to create an account ( required before you can move on). I was unable to complain to GE, did not have the means or ability to do so). Something is wrong with the website.
Is there another way that Alexa can identify first light to be “kitchen lights” and second light to be “TV room lights” etc....

Date: Reviewed in the United States on January 25, 2018
Data:
i LOVE my echo! it has so many features and provides endles entertainment for my 5 year old as well! the only problem, which is driving me NUTS because i use this alot for music.... is when i say something like "play indie pop music" it plays indie christmas music. ITS NOT EVEN CHRISTMAS TIME! i asked her to play sleep music, she played instrumental christmas music. I asked her to play pop music, she played christmas pop!

i reset it, which was annoying because i had to go through the whole set up again, and that did not fix the problem. Christmas music should not activate unless i use the word christmas! arg.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on April 5, 2018
Data:
Setup was easy and already have it controlling our Phillips Hue lights. The built in hub means not needing hubs for the other technology we may add. Next will be getting it setup to control our Fire Boxes with just voice commands.
***UPDATE***
Three months later and it won't connect to our wifi. I went so far as to perform a factory reset on it and went through the setup again and it just will not connect to our wifi even though it was connected for three months. Even moved it to the same room as the router and still nothing. The only option left for me is to return it for a replacement.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on February 15, 2018
Data:
The Echo Plus is an amazing device. Being able to get time, weather, and more just by asking it a question is great. It sounds pretty good when playing music, and being able to use Pandora or Spotify to play music is great. Having the built in home hub is a great feature, and saves about $100 you would normally spend to get a hub.

My only complaint is that it cannot do basic searching. If you ask it a question, you may get an answer, often you do not. If they can improve the searching, I would give it a 5 star rating.

It's still a great device, and worth the money.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on January 10, 2019
Data: Speakers are good and can get loud for a small unit. Good for living rooms and bedrooms but I would not use this outside for a party or anything. I find the Echo useful and it controls my Philips bulbs well. The features are nice too but I don't like that there's still no option for Spanish language on these units in the US. I'd like to get one for my older parents who feel more comfortable communicating in their native tongue. There's an option for Japanese and German but no Spanish. That makes zero sense Amazon. Spanish speakers make up almost 20% of the US!

Date: Reviewed in the United States on January 26, 2018
Data: I like the color, the design, the quality, the responsiveness, and the simplicity in the initial setup. I love that it works with other Bluetooth devices. I was able to pair it with my Sony portable Bluetooth speaker (it did not play on both it was one or the other). I paired it with my iPhone to watch Netflix. I wish it were portable / wireless or had a rechargeable battery option. My biggest issues are with the app. I setup routines that do not appear to work from voice command; I usually have to open the app from my phone and press play (which completely defeats the purpose of a voice command).

Date: Reviewed in the United States on February 18, 2018
Data: This technology is new to me so I am definitely not using all that the echo plus can deliver. If you have no intention of using the home hub part don't bother spending the extra money. I could have easily just gotten the dot. (This was a gift though.) Setup was extremely tedious. Instruction is really poor and going to the website is no help either. I just continued to do the same thing over and over and after two days it finally connected. Bottom line, this is a fun toy. It has also been helpful in the kitchen, quick recipe substitutions, conversions, etc...and Alexa did predict the outcome of the Super Bowl!

Date: Reviewed in the United States on August 10, 2018
Data: It's nice for reminders, timers, shopping lists, but music gets sketchy at times, especially when trying to get it to stay linked to any Echo Dots in the house. The sound quality actually was more impressive than I thought it would be though (and I'm honestly kind of a snob about sound quality). The app gives a bit more control about what the Echo can access on my phone, which is nice for people like me that don't want constant connectivity to the internet world. Overall, once they get the music and Dot connection issues figured out, I'll have nothing negative to say.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on March 4, 2018
Data: So far we like it. Connecting to wifi was a little more tedious than I expected but all was fine once it was done. We have some shoddy wifi providers, so when it goes out we have to reconnect Alexa which is irritating and from time to time response time is incredibly slow or not there at all. Not sure if that has to do with our wifi, but we will have fiber in the next week and are hoping that it makes all the difference. But it is awesome to catch news, turn on lights, control the TV and play games. No doubt this is a good product.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on January 17, 2018
Data: Overall, I'm fairly satisfied with this product. For the price, it functions just as well as you'd expect. Some of my favorite features would be the built-in hub, the quality of sounds (for listening to music), and the level of understanding it has for an AI. There are some ways it could be improved, however. Sometimes, the sound recognition is TOO good. Any word similar to "Alexa" can trigger the device. Also, the skills in the app are very limited and seem a little basic. Other than that, I'm pretty satisfied with this device and would recommend it to anyone who is interested in developing their own smart home.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on November 4, 2017
Data:
We purchased our first Echo in November of 2014, 3 years ago this month. She was the hit of our Thanksgiving dinner celebration that year but could do only a fraction of what she is capable of today. We added smart bulbs like the Philips Hue white and colored bulbs, GE Link and TP Link bulbs, smart plugs, smart wall switches, and smart device timers. We added them over the years as they became available on Amazon. (And on sale!) We had to purchase hubs to run the Philips and GE bulbs when we first started adding bulbs. The 1st Gen Philips hub worked well for about a year and then started having problems with disconnecting from the network and not playing nice with Alexa. Philips finally replaced it under warranty. The Wink hub which controlled the GE bulbs has always worked flawlessly. But whenever we changed our network password, we had to go around and reset all the bulbs, often having to re-register some of them and then go into the Alexa app and have her rediscover them. Perhaps not a big deal when you’re only using a couple bulbs, but a real time waster when almost every bulb in a large 2 story house is a smart bulb.

This Echo Plus allowed me to disconnect the hubs and control everything with Alexa alone. She didn’t discover the bulbs right away. I had to go in and deregister them from their hubs and then rediscover them and add them to the Plus. But now they work flawlessly. Let me tell you how I did that. In your Alexa app, click on the little menu thingie in the upper left hand corner which will open a drop down menu. Select Smart Home from the menu. You’ll see a page showing devices, groups and scenes. Click on the little ? In the upper right hand corner. This will open a page with instructions and clickable commands for deregistering a list of different devices from their hubs and having Alexa discover and connect them to the Echo Plus. It’s a little bit of a pain to have to go around and get serial numbers off the bulbs or turn others on and off, but you only have to do it once, then Alexa has them. And it isn’t difficult. No more running upstairs to push the button on the Philips hub to get bulbs to respond. No more extra hubs sitting around consuming electricity. And no more dealing with the clunky Philips Hue app (If you don’t believe me, go read the reviews for that app.)

Now that everything is connected through Alexa, I have set up Routines to turn a few of our lights on and off and specified times. (Voice commands can still be used to override a routine and they don’t interfere with your routine the next time it is scheduled.) I can also turn them on and off remotely from the Alexa app. I have a routine set for our kitchen Alexa so that when I say, “Alexa, good morning” she will turn on one of the kitchen smart bulbs at 50% brightness and the other at 100% brightness and read me the local weather report. Our bedroom Alexa has a routine that is triggered when I say “Alexa, start my day”. She turns on one of the lights at 20% and reads my morning news flash. How cool is that? Here’s how you set up a routine:

1. Go to the menu and select "Routines."
2. Select the + icon.

From here, you can specify when Alexa will do something, and what it will do.
-- Select "When this happens" to pick a scheduled time for the Routine to run, or enter a word or phrase that will activate it.
-- Select "Add action" to select what the Routine will run. You can add multiple actions, one at a time.
-- Once you have selected a “cue” and an action, select the device you want the Routine to play on.
-- Select "Create" to save the routine.

Groups are also a great feature. You can Group your Echo and Dot device’s together in a group, give the group a name, and then tell Alexa, “Play my <Bruno Mars> playlist on my <downstairs> group. She instantly starts to play it on all the devices in the group. You could also play a single song or a radio station like iHeart or Pandora. We have a large family room/kitchen combo with the Plus on a desk about midway in the room and a Dot connected by 3.5mm Cable to a Heos speaker, with excellent sound. We put the two in a group. The sound is amazing! It’s better than stereo, especially with the new Plus. The Plus is slightly stronger on the treble than the 1st Gen Echo. The Heos is strong on bass. They sync perfectly with each other and never miss a beat. BTW, I rarely used the Heos except for parties before we got the Dot because I was so spoiled by controlling music by voice on our Echo. It was much better than using an app to control the Heos. Now the Heos is used all the time since I can use it with Alexa. Grouping with the Plus makes it that much better. We can also add Echos in other rooms to the group, which we do when we have people over. We can now have the same music playing in the living room/dining room as in the family room. They are easily added-or subtracted in the Alexa app.

Like the regular Echo, this Plus can control all of our white bulbs and the the Hue color bulb by voice, including changing the colors to any color I can think of (pink, teal, red, blue, purple, aqua, etc.) dimming to any percentage and on/off and adding them to routines or group. For example, I can say, “Turn on the downstairs lights” and Alexa will turn on every light I’ve added to that group. The Plus controls our smart plugs and switches just like the regular Echo did and we add those to groups as well. Bulbs, switches and plugs can be a part of several different groups. (The group Holiday lights turned on all the LED lighted pumpkins and orange lights on our banisters when we said, “Alexa, turn on the holiday lights.”

We can also use this Plus like the other Echos, to Drop In on our other rooms. Since we have Echos in just about every room we now have a home intercom system that works beautifully.

We’ve watched Alexa get smarter and smarter almost weekly, from that first day with her 3 years ago. I have no doubt that she will continue learn new skills to make our lives even easier and more fun. (Did I mention that she can switch our older LG TV to PlayStation Vue streaming through our Amazon Fire TV device and start and pause shows by voice through either the Echos or Fire TV remote? Yeah, we dumped our satellite TV provider and now pay less than half with live and recorded streaming. But that’s for another review!)

Date: Reviewed in the United States on October 11, 2018
Data:
The Echo Plus Gen 1 is a great addition to my smart home. It gives me all my original Echo provides plus lets me eliminate my Philips Hue hub and works with all my other Z-wave devices. The Gen-1 form factor is almost identical to the original Echo but with a faster processor and integrated hub. Nice!

I love my Echo/Alexa. Voice control of my smart home and other Amazon devices plus response to information requests (what's new, etc.) and nearly endless entertainment options have made this an integral part of my home life. As an early adopter of the original gen-1 Echo I have been very impressed by how Amazon continues to improve existing operation, add new features and new capabilities.

I got my first Echo in March 2015. Since then I've seen a lot of new capabilities added:
+ A constant integration of more services like Pandora, traffic and Amazon Radio stations
+ Connected home control now with the integrated Z-Wave device hub and control of WiFI smart home devices like those from Belkin and TP-Link.
+ integration with IFTTT (if this then that) service for triggers and actions
+ integration popular services like Google Calendar and much more
+ integrated Amazon purchase/ordering

The list keeps growing. It's part of the beauty of a product that's mostly in the Amazon cloud. New features and capabilities are not dependent solely upon the computing and storage of the Echo device itself.

The Echo is also a very nice bluetooth speaker. It pairs readily with multiple devices - phone, computer and even my Amazon Fire TV so it can provide an enhanced audio experience. With some devices control of tracks can controlled by voice like skip or repeat, etc.

Another essential part of the Echo is the FREE Amazon Echo App . I have it installed on my Kindle Fire HD 8.9in and on my iPhone 6. This provides simple setup and configuration of services and integration with supported connected home devices. It also provides the mobile part of the todo and shopping lists.

The Echo has been a game changer for my home experience. This Echo Plus even more so. It's the closest thing I've used to a computer you can just speak to and be understood - like on the old Star Trek series. I wonder how I lived without it!

I gotta give the Echo Plus 5 stars. Not just for how good it is but in anticipation of all the new things that will surely will come along soon.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on December 19, 2017
Data:
There are many excellent reviews of the new Echo Plus here, so this review is from the POV of someone with limited connection infrastructure, e.g., very rural area, no internet or cable, only satellite service offered, but no signal due to heavy tree cover, beginner smart home user. I never dreamed an Echo would work for me, much less the Echo Plus or smart home. I broke down & purchased an Echo on Prime Day June, 2017 just to try. I receive my internet service solely through an AT&T Velocity hotspot device, typically with only 1 bar of service. I was so excited that the Echo worked perfectly & decided to go out on another limb, purchasing the Echo Plus w/included Hue bulb on Cyber Monday, as well as a Fire TV Stick, figuring I was really pushing the envelope that any would work. All devices worked perfectly! I now have the meager beginnings of a smart home as well as Alexa functionality. I can't tell you how surprised I am! There is an 8-device limit for the hotspot, so wi-fi smart devices are out of the question for me & not sure I have enough signal for any to work anyway. Using the Echo Plus as my only hub, the included Hue bulb connected in seconds, while also tying in with my 1st Echo. So I can use either of the 2 Echos to control the light bulb, connected to a lamp in my living room. What is ideal for my situation is that the Hue bulb does not "count" as a wi-fi device, so does not go toward my device count/limit on the hotspot. Apparently, it is connected directly to the Echo Plus hub. Currently, with one bar of hotspot service, I'm running the Echo Plus, Echo, Fire tablet, Fire TV Stick & Galaxy Express 3 cell, & every now & then, an Echo Tap--all at one time with excellent results! Everything works as if I have hard wired cable or internet, which is simply amazing. Movies, music, etc. run flawlessly.
ALEXA - I don't have a lot of space on my cell, so all I need is the Alexa app to control the bulb when away from home, no need for a separate app AND I already have the Alexa app on my tablet & of course, use Alexa on both Echo's & a Tap.
SMART HOME - The Echo Plus has opened up the smart home market for me. Although it appears limited to the Zigbee IoT protcol, the available choices are varied enough that there are switches, more bulbs, door locks & plugs I'll be able to use now. This thing just came out, so as time goes by, I'm sure more & more skills & IoT stuff will become available. I'm sure the folks at Amazon will make improvements to capabilities as well. And I can do it all with just 1 Echo Plus - no need for additional hubs or devices with my limited internet!
SOUND - I found my 1st Echo sound pretty decent. I am by no means an audiophile, but IMHO Echo Plus sound greatly improved over the Echo. Much richer, more robust & MUCH better bass - yay! My 1st Echo sounds "tinny" now, compared to the Echo Plus.
I am beyond delighted with the performance of the Echo Plus & kudos to Amazon for this "upgrade" to the Echo. I would highly recommend the Echo Plus, especially for those just entering the smart home market with internet challenges. I LOVE MY ECHO PLUS!!!!!

Date: Reviewed in the United States on July 20, 2018
Data:
Incredible piece of technology.
I have this right center of my living room on an island kitchen counter. The mic and speaker goes in every direction and the quality of the sound is quite good. I connected the Echo via Bluetooth to my Sony soundbar on my TV but find the Echo placement and 360 sound more appealing. It's no audiophile equipment but there is good range and decent bass. The sound is more than adequate for any indoor entertaining and loud enough to bother neighbors in my building. The knob on the top works great for adjusting volume. This is my first Echo device and I would imagine having to press volume buttons (on the Echo 2) a large inconvenience and not as precise. For that alone I would recommend this over the regular Echo (2nd generation).

The piece looks quality and is quite sturdy with some weight on it. The rubber material on the bottom has a good grip on the granite counter-- my cat can even rub her scent on it without tipping it over.

This order came with a free Philips Hue Bulb which I installed along with an extra one I bought. I put the 2 bulbs into my living room floor lamp, turned on the light, and all I had to do was say "Alexa, connect my devices". The default names for each bulb was assigned as "First light" and "Second light", so I can have a dimmer floor lamp if I just turned on/off one of the lights by saying "Alexa, turn off the second light". In the Alexa app, I created a 'Group' with "First light" and "Second light" and named the group "The light", so to turn on the lamp with both bulbs shining I just say "Alexa, turn on The light".

I was surprised how easily the bulbs connected to the Echo Plus with its built in hub. I thought I would have to buy a hub bridge to connect to my floor lamp power plug. Apparently there is some technology built directly inside the bulb! I was surprised by that. Awesome.

You will feel like Tony Stark on this device. I added quite a few "Skills" like 'Thunderstorm sounds' and 'Quote of the day' . Alexa always loads them up quickly. Adding songs that you hear to specific playlists on Amazon Music is also a great feature.

I can go on and on and this is only my second day of ownership.

I was lucky to buy this for $100 on Prime Day, but I think for $150 is it pretty expensive considering the Echo 2 is only $100. In my opinion, you will be paying a premium for the Echo Plus and you have to decide if the value is there for you:
1) Taller and 360 sound unit.
2) Volume knob on top that you spin (I think this is a huge benefit over buttons)
3) Built in hub for Hue bulbs. After researching more, there are some cons to this setup if you plan on having more advanced light setups. For me and my floor lamp, it's just perfect.

I highly recommend it and will buy an Echo dot for my bedroom now.
